    "filename": "docs/identity/role-based-access-control/includes/dragon-administrator.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 12,

    "changes": 13,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fidentity%2Frole-based-access-control%2Fincludes%2Fdragon-administrator.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fidentity%2Frole-based-access-control%2Fincludes%2Fdragon-administrator.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Frole-based-access-control%2Fincludes%2Fdragon-administrator.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -4,11 +4,22 @@ description: Dragon Administrator\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: role-based-access-control\n ms.topic: include\n-ms.date: 09/11/2025\n+ms.date: 10/02/2025\n ms.custom: include file\n ---\n \n+Assign the Dragon Administrator role to users who need to do the following tasks:\n \n+- Manage all aspects of the administrative experience in the Dragon admin center\n+- Provision clinical applications\n+- Create and manage the organization hierarchy\n+- Oversee healthcare groups\n+- Manage experiences of various clinical applications embedded in Electronic Health Record (EHR) systems\n+- Configure clinical applications, such as manage settings, view analytics, and handle library objects\n+- Create, manage, and view support tickets for their organization in the Dragon admin center\n+- Create, view, manage, and monitor billing plans for licenses purchased by their organization (additional roles may be required)\n+\n+[Learn more](/industry/healthcare/dragon-admin-center/get-started/)\n \n <!-- autogenerated content starts here -->\n "
  },
  {
    "sha": "c74b96e5e90cdb74aa9faa8523760b21c8214a2f",
    "filename": "docs/identity/role-based-access-control/includes/teams-reader.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 16,
    "deletions": 1,
    "changes": 17,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fidentity%2Frole-based-access-control%2Fincludes%2Fteams-reader.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fidentity%2Frole-based-access-control%2Fincludes%2Fteams-reader.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Frole-based-access-control%2Fincludes%2Fteams-reader.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -4,10 +4,25 @@ description: Teams Reader\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: role-based-access-control\n ms.topic: include\n-ms.date: 07/09/2025\n+ms.date: 10/02/2025\n ms.custom: include file\n ---\n \n+Assign the Teams Reader role to users who need to do the following tasks: \n+\n+- Read settings and administrative information in the Teams admin center, but not perform any management actions\n+- Read the Microsoft Call Quality Dashboard (CQD), but not access any troubleshooting capabilities\n+\n+Users with this role **cannot** do the following tasks:\n+\n+- Cannot view Teams management\n+- Cannot access Meetings & Calls details of users\n+- Cannot access Notifications & Rules management\n+- Cannot access Frontline worker deployment management\n+- Cannot access the advanced collaboration insights dashboard\n+\n+[Learn more](/microsoftteams/using-admin-roles)\n+\n <!-- autogenerated content starts here -->\n \n > [!div class=\"mx-tableFixed\"]"
  },

    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Frole-based-access-control%2Fwhats-new.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -2,13 +2,13 @@\n title: What's new in Microsoft Entra RBAC documentation\n description: Learn about the new features and documentation improvements in Microsoft Entra role-based access control (RBAC).\n \n-author: barclayn\n+author: rolyon\n manager: pmwongera\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: role-based-access-control\n ms.topic: whats-new\n-ms.date: 05/26/2025\n-ms.author: barclayn\n+ms.date: 10/02/2025\n+ms.author: rolyon\n \n ---\n \n@@ -20,6 +20,8 @@ This article provides information about new features and documentation improveme\n \n | Date | Area | Description |\n | --- | --- | --- |\n+| Oct 2025 | Roles | Added [Dragon Administrator](permissions-reference.md#dragon-administrator) role. |\n+| August 2025 | Roles | Added [Teams Reader](permissions-reference.md#teams-reader) role. |\n | June 2025 | Roles | Added [Organizational Data Source Administrator](permissions-reference.md#organizational-data-source-administrator) role. |\n | June 2025 | Administrative units | General availability of restricted management administrative units. See [Restricted management administrative units in Microsoft Entra ID](admin-units-restricted-management.md). |\n | May 2025 | Roles | Updated permissions for multiple roles. See [Microsoft Entra built-in roles](permissions-reference.md). |"
  },

    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,58 @@\n+---\n+title: View a list and description of all system reports available in Permissions Management reports\n+description: View a list and description of all system reports available in Permissions Management.\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n+\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 04/01/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+---\n+\n+\n+# View a list and description of system reports\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire). \n+\n+Microsoft Entra Permissions Management has various types of system reports that capture specific sets of data. These reports allow management, auditors, and administrators to:\n+\n+- Make timely decisions.\n+- Analyze trends and system/user performance.\n+- Identify trends in data and high risk areas so that management can address issues more quickly and improve their efficiency.\n+\n+This article provides you with a list and description of the system reports available in Permissions Management. Depending on the report, you can download it in comma-separated values (**CSV**) format, portable document format (**PDF**), or Microsoft Excel Open XML Spreadsheet (**XLSX**) format.\n+\n+## Download a system report\n+\n+1. In the Permissions Management home page, select the **Reports** tab, and then select the **Systems Reports** subtab.\n+1. In the **Report Name** column, find the report you want, and then select the down arrow to the right of the report name to download the report.\n+\n+    Or, from the ellipses **(...)** menu, select **Download**.\n+\n+    The following message displays: **Successfully Started To Generate On Demand Report.**\n+\n+\n+## Summary of available system reports\n+\n+| Report name                | Type of the report                | File format              | Description               | Availability                | Collated report?                 |\n+|----------------------------|-----------------------------------|--------------------------|---------------------------| ----------------------------|----------------------------------|\n+| Access Key Entitlements and Usage Report                | Summary </p>Detailed                | CSV                 | This report displays: </p> - Access key age, last rotation date, and last usage date availability in the summary report. Use this report to decide when to rotate access keys. </p> - Granted task and Permissions creep index (PCI) score. This report provides supporting information when you want to take the action on the keys.                | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP                 | Yes      |\n+| All Permissions for Identity                 | Summary                 | CSV                | This report lists all the assigned permissions for the selected identities.                | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP            | N/A      |\n+| Group Entitlements and Usage       | Summary                | CSV                | This report tracks all group level entitlements and the permission assignment, PCI. The number of members is also listed as part of this report.                 | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP                 | Yes      |\n+| Identity Permissions                 | Summary                | CSV                 | This report tracks any, or specific, task usage per **User**, **Group**, **Role**, or **App**.                 | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP                 | N/A      |\n+| AWS Role Policy Audit       | Detailed | CSV | This report gives the list of AWS roles, which can be assumed by **User**, **Group**, **resource** or **AWS Role**.                | AWS | N/A      |\n+| Cross Account Access Details| Detailed                 | CSV                 | This report helps track **User**, **Group** from other AWS accounts have cross account access to the specified AWS account.                | AWS                | N/A      |\n+| PCI History                 | Summary                 | CSV                 | This report helps track **Monthly PCI History** for each authorized system. It can be used to plot the trend of the PCI.                 | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP                 | Yes      |\n+| Permissions Analytics Report (PAR)  |     Detailed                 | XSLX, PDF                 | This report lists the different key findings in the selected authorized systems. The key findings include **Super identities**, **Inactive identities**, **Over-provisioned active identities**, **Storage bucket hygiene**, **Access key age (AWS)**, and so on. </p>This report helps administrators to visualize the findings across the organization and make decisions.                    | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP                | Yes for XSLX     |\n+| Role/Policy Details                 | Summary                 | CSV                | This report captures **Assigned/Unassigned** and **Custom/system policy with used/unused condition** for specific or all AWS accounts. </p>Similar data can be captured for Azure and GCP for assigned and unassigned roles.                | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP                 | No      |\n+| User Entitlements and Usage     | Detailed <p>Summary <p> Permissions                | CSV                 | **Summary** This report provides the summary view of all the identities with Permissions Creep Index (PCI), granted and executed tasks per Azure subscription, AWS account, GCP project.     </p>**Detailed** This report provides a detailed view of Azure role assignments, GCP role assignments and AWS policy assignment along with Permissions Creep Index (PCI), tasks used by each identity. </p>**Permissions** This report provides the list of role assignments for Azure, GCP and policy assignments in AWS per identity.                 | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP                | Yes      |\n+\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- For information on how to view system reports in the **Reports** dashboard, see [View system reports in the Reports dashboard](product-reports.md).\n+- For information about how to create, view, and share a system report, see [Create, view, and share a custom report](report-view-system-report.md).\n+- For information about how to create and view a custom report, see [Generate and view a custom report](report-create-custom-report.md).\n+- For information about how to create and view the Permissions analytics report, see [Generate and download the Permissions analytics report](product-permissions-analytics-reports.md)."

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Ferror-codes-onboarding.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Ferror-codes-onboarding.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,105 @@\n+---\n+title: Error codes when onboarding Permissions Management\n+description: Understand potential error codes that may appear during onboarding of Microsoft Entra Permissions Management\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n+\n+ms.topic: reference\n+ms.date: 04/01/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+---\n+\n+# Error codes: Microsoft Entra Permissions Management \n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n+\n+During onboarding, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management may return error messages that an admin can triage. This article lists data collection error messages and their descriptions shown in the Permissions Management UI, along with proposed solutions.\n+\n+\n+## AWS_ACCESSADVISOR_COLLECTION_ERROR \n+\n+This account does not have permissions to view ```Service Last Accessed```. \n+\n+### Proposed solution\n+\n+- Verify that you're signed in using Management Account credentials. The AWS account must have a policy that has permissions to generate, get, or list ```ServiceLastAccessDetails``` or equivalent permissions. \n+- In the AWS Management Console, verify that Service Control Policies (SCPs) are enabled in your organization root.\n+\n+## AWS_CLOUDTRAIL_DISABLED\n+\n+The AWS environment doesn't have CloudTrail configured, or you don't have permissions to access CloudTrail.\n+\n+### Proposed solution\n+\n+CloudTrail is automatically created when an AWS account is created. \n+\n+To access:\n+- Verify you're signed in using Management Account credentials.\n+- Enable CloudTrail as a trusted service in your AWS organization.\n+- Ensure that the AWS account has the CloudTrail managed policies ```AWSCloudTrail_FullAccess```, ```AWSCloudTrail_ReadOnlyAccess```, or is granted equivalent permissions.\n+\n+## AWS_CLOUDTRAIL_S3_ACCESS_DENIED \n+\n+This account doesn't have permissions to access S3 Bucket CloudTrail logs. \n+\n+### Proposed solution\n+\n+Steps to try:\n+- Verify you're signed in using Management Account credentials.\n+- Enable CloudTrail as a trusted service in your AWS organization.\n+- The AWS account must have the CloudTrail managed policy ```AWSCloudTrail_FullAccess``` or have been granted equivalent permissions.\n+- For cross-account access, each account must have an IAM role with an access policy that grants access.\n+- CloudTrail must have the required permissions to deliver log files to the S3 bucket and S3 bucket policies are updated to receive and store log files.\n+\n+## AWS_LDAP_CREDENTIALS_INVALID \n+\n+Invalid LDAP Credentials. \n+\n+### Proposed Solution\n+\n+Verify that the hard drive on your domain controller is not full.\n+\n+\n+## AWS_LDAP_UNREACHABLE \n+\n+Connection failure while trying to access LDAP service. \n+\n+\n+### Proposed solution\n+\n+This issue is common with the AWS Managed Microsoft AD Connector used to enable LDAPS. Verify if the AD connector can communicate via TCP and UDP over the 88 (Kerberos) and 389 (LDAP) ports.\n+\n+## AWS_SYSTEM_ROLE_POLICIES_COLLECTION_ERROR \n+\n+Error during the collection of System role policies.\n+\n+### Proposed solution\n+\n+If your system role policies include Service Control Policies (SCPs), verify you're signed in using Management Account credentials. The AWS account must have the required permissions to display the policies’ details and attached entities.\n+\n+\n+## ERROR_GCP_PROJECT_MIN_PERMISSION\n+\n+Insufficient Project permissions. \n+\n+### Proposed solution\n+\n+Verify you have been granted the correct IAM roles or roles with equivalent permissions that grant access to the project: *Organization Admin*, *Security Admin*, or *Project IAM Admin*.\n+\n+\n+## ERROR_NO_IDENTIFIER_URIS_IN_APP\n+\n+No Identifier URIs configured for app. \n+\n+### Proposed solution\n+\n+- Verify the application configuration for the configured Identifier URI’s in the portal. \n+- Check the Microsoft Entra application’s manifest file. \n+\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- For information on how to onboard an Amazon Web Services (AWS) account, see [Onboard an Amazon Web Services (AWS) account](onboard-aws.md).\n+- For information on how to onboard an account after initial onboarding, see [Add an account/subscription/project after onboarding](onboard-add-account-after-onboarding.md)"
  },

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Ffaqs.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Ffaqs.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,203 @@\n+---\n+title: Frequently asked questions (FAQs) about Microsoft Entra Permissions Management\n+description: Frequently asked questions (FAQs) about Microsoft Entra Permissions Management.\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n+\n+ms.topic: faq\n+ms.date: 04/01/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+---\n+\n+# Frequently asked questions (FAQs)\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n+\n+This article answers frequently asked questions (FAQs) about Microsoft Entra Permissions Management.\n+\n+## What's Microsoft Entra Permissions Management?\n+\n+Microsoft Entra Permissions Management (Permissions Management) is a cloud infrastructure entitlement management (CIEM) solution that provides comprehensive visibility into permissions assigned to all identities. For example, over-privileged workload and user identities, actions, and resources across multicloud infrastructures in Microsoft Azure, Amazon Web Services (AWS), and Google Cloud Platform (GCP). Permissions Management detects, automatically right-sizes, and continuously monitors unused and excessive permissions. It deepens the Zero Trust security strategy by augmenting the least privilege access principle.\n+\n+## What are the prerequisites to use Permissions Management?\n+\n+Permissions Management supports data collection from AWS, GCP, and/or Microsoft Azure. For data collection and analysis, customers are required to have a Microsoft Entra account to use Permissions Management.\n+\n+<a name='can-a-customer-use-permissions-management-if-they-have-other-identities-with-access-to-their-iaas-platform-that-arent-yet-in-azure-ad'></a>\n+\n+## Can a customer use Permissions Management if they have other identities with access to their IaaS platform that aren't yet in Microsoft Entra ID?\n+\n+Yes, a customer can detect, mitigate, and monitor the risk for AWS IAM or GCP accounts, or from other identity providers such as Okta or AWS IAM.\n+\n+## Where can customers access Permissions Management?\n+\n+Customers can access the Permissions Management interface from the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com/) .\n+\n+## Can noncloud customers use Permissions Management on-premises?\n+\n+No, Permissions Management is a hosted cloud offering.\n+\n+## Can non-Azure customers use Permissions Management?\n+\n+Yes, non-Azure customers can use our solution. Permissions Management is a multicloud solution so even customers who have no subscription to Azure can benefit from it.\n+\n+## Is Permissions Management available for tenants hosted in the European Union (EU)?\n+\n+Yes, Permissions Management is currently for tenants hosted in the European Union (EU).\n+\n+<a name='if-im-already-using-azure-ad--privileged-identity-management-pim-for-azure-what-value-does-permissions-management-provide'></a>\n+\n+## If I'm already using Microsoft Entra ID  Privileged Identity Management (PIM) for Azure, what value does Permissions Management provide?\n+\n+Permissions Management complements Microsoft Entra PIM. Microsoft Entra PIM provides just-in-time access for admin roles in Azure and Microsoft Online Services and apps that use groups. Permissions Management allows multicloud discovery, remediation, and monitoring of privileged access across Azure, AWS, and GCP.\n+\n+## What public cloud infrastructures does Permissions Management support?\n+\n+Permissions Management currently supports the three major public clouds: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Google Cloud Platform (GCP), and Microsoft Azure.\n+\n+## Does Permissions Management support hybrid environments?\n+\n+Permissions Management currently doesn't support hybrid environments.\n+\n+## What types of identities does Permissions Management support?\n+\n+Permissions Management supports user identities (for example, employees, customers, external partners) and workload identities (for example, virtual machines, containers, web apps, serverless functions).\n+\n+## Is Permissions Management available in Government Cloud?\n+\n+No, Permissions Management is currently not available in Government clouds.\n+\n+## Is Permissions Management available for sovereign clouds?\n+\n+No, Permissions Management is currently not available in sovereign Clouds.\n+\n+## How does Permissions Management collect insights about permissions usage?\n+\n+Permissions Management has a data collector that collects access permissions that are assigned to various identities, activity logs, and resources metadata. The data collector provides full visibility into permissions granted to all identities to access the resources and details on usage of granted permissions.\n+\n+## How does Permissions Management evaluate cloud permissions risk?\n+\n+Permissions Management offers granular visibility into all identities and their permissions granted versus used, across cloud infrastructures to uncover any action performed by any identity on any resource. The visibility isn't limited to just user identities, but also workload identities such as virtual machines, access keys, containers, and scripts. The dashboard gives an overview of permission profile to locate the riskiest identities and resources.\n+\n+## What is the Permissions Creep Index?\n+\n+The Permissions Creep Index (PCI) is a quantitative measure of risk associated with an identity or role determined by comparing permissions granted versus permissions exercised. It allows users to instantly evaluate the level of risk associated with the number of unused or over-provisioned permissions across identities and resources. It measures how much damage identities can cause based on the permissions they have.\n+\n+## How can customers use Permissions Management to delete unused or excessive permissions?\n+\n+Permissions Management allows users to right-size excessive permissions and automate least privilege policy enforcement with just a few clicks. The solution continuously analyzes historical permission usage data for each identity and gives customers the ability to right-size the permissions of that identity to permissions that are only being used for day-to-day operations. All unused and other risky permissions can be automatically removed.\n+\n+## Why is a user I deleted still visible in the Analytics tab?\n+\n+Check to see if the user was assigned a *Classic Administrator* role. Classic admin roles don't go away when a user is deleted. To resolve this, go to the [Classic admin page](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2268264) and delete that role assignment separately for the user.\n+\n+## How can customers grant permissions on-demand with Permissions Management?\n+\n+For any break-glass or one-off scenarios where an identity needs to perform a specific set of actions on a set of specific resources, the identity can request those permissions on-demand for a limited period with a self-service workflow. Customers can either use the built-in workflow engine or their IT service management (ITSM) tool. The user experience is the same for any identity type, identity source (local, enterprise directory, or federated) and cloud.\n+\n+## What is the difference between permissions on-demand and just-in-time access?\n+\n+Just-in-time (JIT) access is a method used to enforce the principle of least privilege to ensure identities are given the minimum level of permissions to perform the task at hand. Permissions on-demand are a type of JIT access that allows the temporary elevation of permissions, enabling identities to access resources on a by-request, timed basis.\n+\n+## How can customers monitor permissions usage with Permissions Management?\n+\n+Customers only need to track the evolution of their Permission Creep Index (PCI) to monitor permissions usage. Customers can monitor PCI in the **Analytics** tab from their Permissions Management dashboard.\n+\n+## Can customers generate permissions usage reports?\n+\n+Yes, Permissions Management has various types of system report available that capture specific data sets. These reports allow customers to:\n+- Make timely decisions.\n+- Analyze usage trends and system/user performance.\n+- Identify high-risk areas.\n+\n+For information about permissions usage reports, see [Generate and download the Permissions analytics report](product-permissions-analytics-reports.md).\n+\n+## Does Permissions Management integrate with third-party ITSM (Information Technology Service Management) tools?\n+\n+Integration with ITSM tools, such as ServiceNow, is in the future roadmap.\n+\n+## How is Permissions Management being deployed?\n+\n+Customers assigned the [Permissions Management Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#permissions-management-administrator) role must first onboard Permissions Management to their Microsoft Entra tenant, and then onboard their AWS accounts, GCP projects, and Azure subscriptions. More details about onboarding can be found in our [product documentation](onboard-enable-tenant.md).\n+\n+## How long does it take to deploy Permissions Management?\n+\n+It depends on each customer and how many AWS accounts, GCP projects, and Azure subscriptions they have.\n+\n+## Once Permissions Management is deployed, how fast can I get permissions insights?\n+\n+Once fully onboarded with data collection setup, customers can access permissions usage insights within hours. Our machine-learning engine refreshes the Permission Creep Index every hour so that customers can start their risk assessment right away.\n+\n+## Is Permissions Management collecting and storing sensitive personal data?\n+\n+No, Permissions Management doesn't have access to sensitive personal data.\n+\n+## Where can I find more information about Permissions Management?\n+\n+You can read our [blog](https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-entra-azure-ad-blog/bg-p/Identity) and visit our [web page](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/business/identity-access/microsoft-entra-permissions-management). You can also get in touch with your Microsoft point of contact to schedule a demo.\n+\n+## What is the data destruction/decommission process?\n+\n+If a customer initiates a free Permissions Management 45-day trial and does not convert to a paid license within 45 days of the trial expiration, all collected data is deleted within 30 days of the trial expiration date.  \n+\n+If a customer decides to discontinue licensing the service, all previously collected data is deleted within 30 days of license termination.\n+\n+Customers can also remove, export or modify specific data if a [Permissions Management Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#permissions-management-administrator) using the Permissions Management service files an official Data Subject Request. To file a request:\n+\n+If you're an enterprise customer, you can contact your Microsoft representative, account team, or tenant admin to file a high-priority IcM support ticket requesting a Data Subject Request. Do not include details or any personally identifiable information in the IcM request. We'll reach out to you for these details only after an IcM is filed.\n+\n+If you're a self-service customer (you set up a trial or paid license in the Microsoft 365 admin center) you can contact the Permissions Management privacy team by selecting your profile drop-down menu, then **Account Settings** in Permissions Management. Follow the instructions to make a Data Subject Request.\n+\n+Learn more about [Azure Data Subject Requests](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2245178).\n+\n+<a name='do-i-require-a-license-to-use-entra-permissions-management-'></a>\n+\n+## Do I require a license to use Microsoft Entra Permissions Management? \n+\n+Yes, as of July 1, 2022, new customers must acquire a free 45-day trial license or a paid license to use the service. You can enable a trial here: [https://aka.ms/TryPermissionsManagement](https://aka.ms/TryPermissionsManagement) or you can directly purchase resource-based licenses here: [https://aka.ms/BuyPermissionsManagement](https://aka.ms/BuyPermissionsManagement) \n+\n+## How is Permissions Management priced? \n+\n+Permissions Management is $125 per resources/year ($10.40 per resource/month). Permissions Management requires licenses for workloads, which include any resource that uses compute or memory. \n+\n+## Do I need to pay for all resources?\n+\n+Although Permissions Management supports all resources, Microsoft only requires licenses for billable resources per cloud environment. To learn more about billable resources, visit [View billable resources listed in your authorization system](product-data-billable-resources.md)\n+\n+## How do I calculate the number of billable resources I have? \n+\n+To calculate the billable resources you have across your multicloud infrastructure, you must first activate a [45-day free trial](https://aka.ms/TryPermissionsManagement) of Permissions Management or [purchase a paid license](https://aka.ms/BuyPermissionsManagement). In Permissions Management, select **Settings** (gear icon), then click the **Billable Resources** tab. View the amount of billable resources in the **Total Number of Licenses** column.\n+\n+## What do I do if I’m using the legacy version of the CloudKnox service?  \n+\n+We are currently working on developing a migration plan to help customers on the original CloudKnox service move to the new Microsoft Entra Permissions Management service later in 2022.   \n+\n+<a name='can-i-use-entra-permissions-management-in-the-eu--'></a>\n+\n+## Can I use Microsoft Entra Permissions Management in the EU?  \n+\n+Yes, the product is compliant.  \n+\n+## How to I enable one of the new 18 languages supported in the GA release? \n+\n+We are now localized in 18 languages. We respect your browser setting or you can manually enable your language of choice by adding a query string suffix to your Microsoft Entra Permissions Management URL:  \n+\n+`?lang=xx-XX` \n+\n+Where xx-XX is one of the following available language parameters: 'cs-CZ', 'de-DE', 'en-US', 'es-ES', 'fr-FR', 'hu-HU', 'id-ID', 'it-IT', 'ja-JP', 'ko-KR', 'nl-NL', 'pl-PL', 'pt-BR', 'pt-PT', 'ru-RU', 'sv-SE', 'tr-TR', 'zh-CN', or 'zh-TW'. \n+\n+## Resources\n+\n+- [Microsoft Entra blog](https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-entra-azure-ad-blog/bg-p/Identity)\n+- [Permissions Management web page](https://microsoft.com/security/business/identity-access-management/permissions-management)\n+- For more information about Microsoft's privacy and security terms, see [Commercial Licensing Terms](https://www.microsoft.com/licensing/terms/product/ForallOnlineServices/all). \n+- For more information about Microsoft's data processing and security terms when you subscribe to a product, see [Microsoft Products and Services Data Protection Addendum (DPA)](https://www.microsoft.com/licensing/docs/view/Microsoft-Products-and-Services-Data-Protection-Addendum-DPA).\n+- For more information, see [Azure Data Subject Requests for the GDPR and CCPA](/compliance/regulatory/gdpr-dsr-azure).\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- For an overview of Permissions Management, see [What's Microsoft Entra Permissions Management?](overview.md).\n+- Deepen your learning with the [Introduction to Microsoft Entra Permissions Management](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2240016) learn module.\n+- For information on how to onboard Permissions Management in your organization, see [Enable Permissions Management in your organization](onboard-enable-tenant.md)."
  },
  {
    "sha": "fd861f0cd0f16cc5eaf5d2d58febfcc417dcf527",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/how-to-add-remove-role-task.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 107,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 107,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-add-remove-role-task.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-add-remove-role-task.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-add-remove-role-task.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,107 @@\n+---\n+title: Add and remove roles and tasks for groups, users, and service accounts for Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud Platform (GCP) identities in the Remediation dashboard in Permissions Management\n+description: How to attach and detach permissions for groups, users, and service accounts for Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud Platform (GCP) identities in the Remediation dashboard in Permissions Management.\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n+\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 04/01/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+---\n+\n+# Add and remove roles and tasks for Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud Platform (GCP) identities\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n+\n+This article describes how you can add and remove roles and tasks for Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud Platform (GCP) identities using the **Remediation** dashboard.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> To view the **Remediation** tab, your must have **Viewer**, **Controller**, or **Administrator** permissions. To make changes on this tab, you must have **Controller** or **Administrator** permissions. If you don't have these permissions, contact your system administrator.\n+\n+## View permissions\n+\n+1. On the Permissions Management home page, select the **Remediation** tab, and then select the **Permissions** subtab.\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select **Azure** or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select the accounts you want to access.\n+1. From the **Search For** dropdown, select **Group**, **User**, or **APP**.\n+1. To search for more parameters, you can make a selection from the **User States**, **Permission Creep Index**, and **Task Usage** dropdowns.\n+1. Select **Apply**.\n+    Microsoft Entra ID displays a list of groups, users, and service accounts that match your criteria.\n+1. In **Enter a username**, enter or select a user.\n+1. In **Enter a Group Name**, enter or select a group, then select **Apply**.\n+1. Make a selection from the results list.\n+\n+    The table displays the **Username** **Domain/Account**, **Source**, **Resource** and **Current Role**.\n+\n+\n+## Add a role\n+\n+1. On the Permissions Management home page, select the **Remediation** tab, and then select the **Permissions** subtab.\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select **Azure** or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select the accounts you want to access.\n+1. From the **Search For** dropdown, select **Group**, **User**, or **APP/Service Account**, and then select **Apply**.\n+1. Make a selection from the results list.\n+\n+1. To attach a role, select **Add role**.\n+1. In the **Add Role** page, from the **Available Roles** list, select the plus sign **(+)** to move the role to the **Selected Roles** list.\n+1. When you have finished adding roles, select **Submit**.\n+1. When the following message displays: **Are you sure you want to change permission?**, select:\n+    - **Generate Script** to generate a script where you can manually add/remove the permissions you selected.\n+    - **Execute** to change the permission.\n+    - **Close** to cancel the action.\n+\n+## Remove a role\n+\n+1. On the Permissions Management home page, select the **Remediation** tab, and then select the **Permissions** subtab.\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select **Azure** or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select the accounts you want to access.\n+1. From the **Search For** dropdown, select **Group**, **User**, or **APP/Service Account**, and then select **Apply**.\n+1. Make a selection from the results list.\n+\n+1. To remove a role, select **Remove Role**.\n+1. In the **Remove Role** page, from the **Available Roles** list, select the plus sign **(+)** to move the role to the **Selected Roles** list.\n+1. When you have finished selecting roles, select **Submit**.\n+1. When the following message displays: **Are you sure you want to change permission?**, select:\n+    - **Generate Script** to generate a script where you can manually add/remove the permissions you selected.\n+    - **Execute** to change the permission.\n+    - **Close** to cancel the action.\n+\n+## Add a task\n+\n+1. On the Permissions Management home page, select the **Remediation** tab, and then select the **Permissions** subtab.\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select **Azure** or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select the accounts you want to access.\n+1. From the **Search For** dropdown, select **Group**, **User**, or **APP/Service Account**, and then select **Apply**.\n+1. Make a selection from the results list.\n+\n+1. To attach a role, select **Add Tasks**.\n+1. In the **Add Tasks** page, from the **Available Tasks** list, select the plus sign **(+)** to move the task to the **Selected Tasks** list.\n+1. When you have finished adding tasks, select **Submit**.\n+1. When the following message displays: **Are you sure you want to change permission?**, select:\n+    - **Generate Script** to generate a script where you can manually add/remove the permissions you selected.\n+    - **Execute** to change the permission.\n+    - **Close** to cancel the action.\n+\n+## Remove a task\n+\n+1. On the Permissions Management home page, select the **Remediation** tab, and then select the **Permissions** subtab.\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select **Azure** or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select the accounts you want to access.\n+1. From the **Search For** dropdown, select **Group**, **User**, or **APP/Service Account**, and then select **Apply**.\n+1. Make a selection from the results list.\n+\n+1. To remove a task, select **Remove Tasks**.\n+1. In the **Remove Tasks** page, from the **Available Tasks** list, select the plus sign **(+)** to move the task to the **Selected Tasks** list.\n+1. When you have finished selecting tasks, select **Submit**.\n+1. When the following message displays: **Are you sure you want to change permission?**, select:\n+    - **Generate Script** to generate a script where you can manually add/remove the permissions you selected.\n+    - **Execute** to change the permission.\n+    - **Close** to cancel the action.\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+\n+- For information on how to view existing roles/policies, requests, and permissions, see [View roles/policies, requests, and permission in the Remediation dashboard](ui-remediation.md).\n+- To view information about roles/policies, see [View information about roles/policies](how-to-view-role-policy.md)."
  },
  {
    "sha": "e8287f61b08d1754ea4d31ae8443df9d284e788d",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/how-to-add-remove-user-to-group.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 50,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 50,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-add-remove-user-to-group.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-add-remove-user-to-group.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-add-remove-user-to-group.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,50 @@\n+---\n+title: Add or remove a user in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management through the Microsoft Entra admin center\n+description: How to add or remove a user in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management through the Microsoft Enter admin center.\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n+\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 05/02/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+---\n+\n+# Add or remove a user in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n+\n+This article describes how you can add or remove a new user for a group in Permissions Management. \n+\n+> [!NOTE] \n+> Permissions Management entitlements work through group-based access. To add a new user, you must add a user to a group through Microsoft Entra ID.\n+\n+## Add a user\n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com/#home) as at least a [Billing Administrator](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2254515).\n+1. Browse to **Entra ID**, then select **Go to Microsoft Entra ID**. \n+1. From the navigation pane, go to **Entra ID** > **Groups** > **All groups**.\n+1. Select the group name for the group you want to add the user to.\n+1. From the group's **Manage** menu, click **Members**.\n+1. Click **+ Add members**, then search for the user you want to add from the list.\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > In order to add a user to a group, you must be the group owner. If you're not the owner of the selected group, please reach out to the group owner. If you don't know who the owner of the group is, select **Owners** under the group's **Manage** menu.\n+1. Click **Select**. Your user has been added. \n+1. Click the **Refresh** button to refresh your screen and view the user you've added.\n+\n+## Remove a user\n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com/#home) as at least a [Billing Administrator](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2254515).\n+1. Browse to **Entra ID**, then select **Go to Microsoft Entra ID**. \n+1. From the navigation pane, go to **Entra ID** > **Groups** > **All groups**.\n+1. Select the group name for the group you want to remove the user from.\n+1. From the groups **Manage** menu, click **Members**.\n+1. Search for the user you want to remove from the list, then check the box next to their name.\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > In order to remove a user from a group, you must be the group owner. If you're not the owner of the selected group, please reach out to the group owner. If you don't know who the owner of the group is, select **Owners** under the group's **Manage** menu.\n+1. Click **X Remove**, then click **Yes**. The user is removed from the group.\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- For more information on managing users and groups, see [Manage users and groups with the User management dashboard](ui-user-management.md)."
  },
  {
    "sha": "ece8c5da658a459d3ea5fb4bbd98d8eac9616b14",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/how-to-attach-detach-permissions.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 71,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 71,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-attach-detach-permissions.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-attach-detach-permissions.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-attach-detach-permissions.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,71 @@\n+---\n+title: Attach and detach permissions for users, roles, and groups for Amazon Web Services (AWS) identities in the Remediation dashboard\n+description: How to attach and detach permissions for users, roles, and groups for Amazon Web Services (AWS) identities in the Remediation dashboard in Permissions Management.\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n+\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 04/01/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+---\n+\n+# Attach and detach policies for Amazon Web Services (AWS) identities\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n+\n+This article describes how you can attach and detach permissions for users, roles, and groups for Amazon Web Services (AWS) identities using the **Remediation** dashboard.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> To view the **Remediation** tab, your must have **Viewer**, **Controller**, or **Administrator** permissions. To make changes on this tab, you must have **Controller** or **Administrator** permissions. If you don't have these permissions, contact your system administrator.\n+\n+## View permissions\n+\n+1. On the Permissions Management home page, select the **Remediation** tab, and then select the **Permissions** subtab.\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select **AWS**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select the accounts you want to access.\n+1. From the **Search For** dropdown, select **Group**, **User**, or **Role**.\n+1. To search for more parameters, you can make a selection from the **User States**, **Permission Creep Index**, and **Task Usage** dropdowns.\n+1. Select **Apply**.\n+    Permissions Management displays a list of users, roles, or groups that match your criteria.\n+1. In **Enter a username**, enter or select a user.\n+1. In **Enter a group name**, enter or select a group, then select **Apply**.\n+1. Make a selection from the results list.\n+\n+    The table displays the related **Username** **Domain/Account**, **Source** and **Policy Name**.\n+\n+\n+## Attach policies\n+\n+1. On the Permissions Management home page, select the **Remediation** tab, and then select the **Permissions** subtab.\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select **AWS**.\n+1. In **Enter a username**, enter or select a user.\n+1. In **Enter a Group Name**, enter or select a group, then select **Apply**.\n+1. Make a selection from the results list.\n+1. To attach a policy, select **Attach Policies**.\n+1. In the **Attach Policies** page, from the **Available policies** list, select the plus sign **(+)** to move the policy to the **Selected policies** list.\n+1. When you have finished adding policies, select **Submit**.\n+1. When the following message displays: **Are you sure you want to change permission?**, select:\n+    - **Generate Script** to generate a script where you can manually add/remove the permissions you selected.\n+    - **Execute** to change the permission.\n+    - **Close** to cancel the action.\n+\n+## Detach policies\n+\n+1. On the Permissions Management Permissions Management home page, select the **Remediation** tab, and then select the **Permissions** subtab.\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select **AWS**.\n+1. In **Enter a username**, enter or select a user.\n+1. In **Enter a Group Name**, enter or select a group, then select **Apply**.\n+1. Make a selection from the results list.\n+1. To remove a policy, select **Detach Policies**.\n+1. In the **Detach Policies** page, from the **Available policies** list, select the plus sign **(+)** to move the policy to the **Selected policies** list.\n+1. When you have finished selecting policies, select **Submit**.\n+1. When the following message displays: **Are you sure you want to change permission?**, select:\n+    - **Generate Script** to generate a script where you can manually add/remove the permissions you selected.\n+    - **Execute** to change the permission.\n+    - **Close** to cancel the action.\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- To create or approve a request for permissions, see [Create or approve a request for permissions](how-to-create-approve-privilege-request.md)."
  },
  {
    "sha": "4627af4f4d52e022de1aab773994e68bfb81d682",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/how-to-audit-trail-results.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 36,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 36,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-audit-trail-results.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-audit-trail-results.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-audit-trail-results.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,36 @@\n+---\n+title: Generate an on-demand report from a query in the Audit dashboard in Permissions Management\n+description: How to generate an on-demand report from a query in the **Audit** dashboard in Permissions Management.\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n+\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 04/01/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+---\n+\n+# Generate an on-demand report from a query\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n+\n+This article describes how you can generate an on-demand report from a query in the **Audit** dashboard in Permissions Management. You can:\n+\n+- Run a report on-demand.\n+- Schedule and run a report as often as you want.\n+- Share a report with other members of your team and management.\n+\n+## Generate a custom report on-demand\n+\n+1. In the Permissions Management home page, select the **Audit** tab.\n+\n+    Permissions Management displays the query options available to you.\n+1. In the **Audit** dashboard, select **Search** to run the query.\n+1. Select **Export**.\n+\n+    Permissions Management generates the report and exports it in comma-separated values (**CSV**) format, portable document format (**PDF**), or Microsoft Excel Open XML Spreadsheet (**XLSX**) format.\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- For information on how to view system reports, see [Generate and view a system report in Permissions Management](report-view-system-report.md)"
  },
  {
    "sha": "e57e6014ba711d1c7c891ed53c8d1807d6683d2b",

    "status": "added",
    "additions": 44,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 44,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-clone-role-policy.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-clone-role-policy.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-clone-role-policy.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,44 @@\n+---\n+title: Clone a role/policy in the Remediation dashboard in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management\n+description: How to clone a role/policy in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management.\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n+\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 04/01/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+---\n+\n+# Clone a role/policy in the Remediation dashboard\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n+\n+This article describes how you can use the **Remediation** dashboard in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management to clone roles/policies for the Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud Platform (GCP) authorization systems.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> To view the **Remediation** tab, you must have **Viewer**, **Controller**, or **Administrator** permissions. To make changes on this tab, you must have **Controller** or **Administrator** permissions. If you don't have these permissions, contact your system administrator.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Microsoft Azure uses the term *role* for what other Cloud providers call *policy*. Permissions Management automatically makes this terminology change when you select the authorization system type. In the user documentation, we use *role/policy* to refer to both.\n+\n+## Clone a role/policy\n+\n+1. On the Permissions Management home page, select the **Remediation** tab, and then select the **Role/Policies** tab.\n+1. Select the role/policy you want to clone, and from the **Actions** column, select **Clone**.\n+1. **(AWS Only)** In the **Clone** box, the **Clone Resources** and **Clone Conditions** checkboxes are automatically selected.\n+    Deselect the boxes if the resources and conditions are different from what is displayed.\n+1. Enter a name for each authorization system that was selected in the **Policy Name** boxes, and then select **Next**.\n+1. If the data collector hasn't been given controller privileges, the following message displays: **Only online/controller-enabled authorization systems can be submitted for cloning.**\n+\n+   To clone this role manually, download the script and JSON file.\n+\n+1. Select **Submit**.\n+1. Refresh the **Role/Policies** tab to see the role/policy you cloned.\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+\n+- To view existing roles/policies, requests, and permissions, see [View roles/policies, requests, and permission in the Remediation dashboard](ui-remediation.md).\n+- To view information about roles/policies, see [View information about roles/policies](how-to-view-role-policy.md)"
  },

    "sha": "fd93da1da5a6e549f4c560eb055186a4af0ba1df",

    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-configure-aws-iam.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,64 @@\n+---\n+title: Configure AWS IAM Identity Center as an identity provider\n+description: How to configure AWS IAM Identity Center as an identity provider.\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n+\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 04/01/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+---\n+\n+# Configure AWS IAM Identity Center as an identity provider (preview)\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n+\n+If you're an Amazon Web Services (AWS) customer who uses the AWS IAM Identity Center, you can configure the Identity Center as an identity provider in Permissions Management. Configuring your AWS IAM Identity Center information allows you to receive more accurate data for your identities in Permissions Management.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Configuring AWS IAM Identity Center as an identity provider is an optional step. By configuring identity provider information, Permissions Management can read user and role access configured at AWS IAM Identity Center. Admins can see the augmented view of assigned permissions to the identities. You can return to these steps to configure an IdP at any time.\n+\n+## How to configure AWS IAM Identity Center as an identity provider\n+\n+1. If the **Data Collectors** dashboard isn't displayed when Permissions Management launches, select **Settings** (gear icon), and then select the **Data Collectors** subtab. \n+\n+\n+2. On the **Data Collectors** dashboard, select **AWS**, and then select **Create Configuration**. If a Data Collector already exists in your AWS account and you want to add AWS IAM integration, then: \n+    - Select the Data Collector for which you want to configure AWS IAM. \n+    - Click on the ellipsis next to the **Authorization Systems Status**. \n+    - Select **Integrate Identity Provider**. \n+\n+3. On the **Integrate Identity provider (IdP)** page, select the box for **AWS IAM Identity Center**. \n+\n+4. Fill in the following fields:\n+    - The **AWS IAM Identity Center Region**. Specify the region where AWS IAM Identity Center is installed. All data configured in the IAM Identity Center  \n+    is stored in the Region where the IAM Identity Center is installed.   \n+    - Your **AWS Management Account ID**\n+    - Your **AWS Management Account Role**\n+\n+5. Select **Launch Management Account Template**. The template opens in a new window. \n+6. If the Management Account stack is created with the CloudFormation Template as part of the previous onboarding steps, update the stack by running ``EnableSSO`` as true. Running this command creates a new stack when running the Management Account Template. \n+\n+The template execution attaches the AWS managed policy  ``AWSSSOReadOnly`` and the newly created custom policy ``SSOPolicy`` to the AWS IAM role that allows Microsoft Entra Permissions Management to collect organizational information. The following details are requested in the template. All fields are prepopulated, and you can edit the data as you need: \n+- **Stack name** – The Stack name is the name of the AWS stack for creating the required AWS resources for Permissions Management to collect organizational information. The default value is ``mciem-org-<tenant-id>``. \n+\n+- **CFT Parameters**\n+    - **OIDC Provider Role Name** – Name of the IAM Role OIDC Provider that can assume the role. The default value is the OIDC account role (as entered in Permissions Management).\n+\n+    - **Org Account Role Name** - Name of the IAM Role. The default value is prepopulated with the Management account role name (as entered in Microsoft Entra PM).\n+\n+    - **true** – Enables AWS SSO. The default value is ``true`` when the template is launched from the Configure Identity Provider (IdP) page, otherwise the default is ``false``. \n+\n+    - **OIDC Provider Account ID** – The Account ID where the OIDC Provider is created. The default value is the OIDC Provider Account ID (as entered in Permissions Management). \n+\n+    - **Tenant ID** – ID of the tenant where the application is created. The default value is ``tenant-id`` (the configured tenant). \n+7. Click **Next** to review and confirm the information you've entered.\n+\n+8. Click **Verify Now & Save**.\n+\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- For information on how to attach and detach permissions AWS identities, see [Attach and detach policies for AWS identities](how-to-attach-detach-permissions.md)."
  },

    "sha": "eca383b169690c9417d67bd03eb8794ee47aa392",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/how-to-configure-okta-as-an-identity-provider.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 111,

    "changes": 111,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-configure-okta-as-an-identity-provider.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-configure-okta-as-an-identity-provider.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fhow-to-configure-okta-as-an-identity-provider.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,111 @@\n+---\n+title: Configure Okta as an identity provider\n+description: How to configure Okta as an identity provider in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management.\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n+\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 04/01/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+---\n+\n+# Configure Okta as an identity provider (preview)\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n+\n+This article describes how to integrate Okta as an identity provider (IdP) for an Amazon Web Services (AWS) account in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management. \n+\n+Permissions Required:\n+\n+\n+| **Account**                  | **Permissions Required**                                         |**Why?**                   |\n+|-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------|\n+| Permissions Management   | Permissions Management Administrator     | Admin can create and edit the AWS authorization system onboarding configuration.   | \n+| Okta                 | API Access Management Administrator     | Admin can add the application in the Okta portal and add or edit the API scope.    |\n+| AWS   | AWS permissions explicitly     |  Admin should be able to run the cloudformation stack to create  1. AWS Secret in Secrets Manager; 2. Managed policy to allow the role to read the AWS secret. | \n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> While configuring the Amazon Web Services (AWS) app in Okta, the suggested AWS role group syntax is (```aws#{account alias]#{role name}#{account #]```).\n+> Sample RegEx pattern for the group filter name are:\n+> - ```^aws\\#\\S+\\#?{{role}}[\\w\\-]+)\\#(?{{accountid}}\\d+)$```\n+> - ```aws_(?{{accountid}}\\d+)_(?{{role}}[a-zA-Z0-9+=,.@\\-_]+)```\n+> Permissions Management reads default suggested filters. Custom RegEx expression for group syntax is not supported.\n+\n+## How to configure Okta as an identity provider\n+\n+1. Log in to the Okta portal with API Access Management Administrator. \n+2. Create a new **Okta API Services Application**. \n+3. In the Admin Console, go to Applications. \n+4. On the Create a new app integration page, select **API Services**.\n+5. Enter a name for your app integration and click **Save**. \n+6. Copy the **Client ID** for future use.  \n+7. In the **Client Credentials** section of the General tab, click **Edit** to change the client authentication method. \n+8. Select **Public key/Private key** as the Client authentication method. \n+9. Leave the default **Save keys in Okta**, then click **Add key**. \n+10. Click **Add** and in the **Add a public key** dialog, either paste your own public key or click **Generate new key** to autogenerate a new 2048-bit RSA key. \n+11. Copy **Public Key Id** for future use.  \n+12. Click **Generate new key** and the public and private keys appear in JWK format. \n+13. Click **PEM**. The private key appears in PEM format. \n+    This is your only opportunity to save the private key. Click **Copy to clipboard** to copy the private key and store it somewhere safe. \n+14. Click **Done**. The new public key is now registered with the app and appears in a table in the **PUBLIC KEYS** section of the **General** tab. \n+15. From the Okta API scopes tab, grant these scopes:\n+    - okta.users.read\n+    - okta.groups.read\n+    - okta.apps.read\n+16. Optional. Click the **Application rate limits** tab to adjust the rate-limit capacity percentage for this service application. By default, each new application sets this percentage at 50 percent. \n+\n+### Convert public key to a Base64 string\n+\n+1. See instructions for [using a personal access token (PAT)](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2249174).\n+\n+### Find your Okta URL (also called an Okta domain)\n+\n+This Okta URL/Okta domain is saved in the AWS secret.\n+\n+1. Sign in to your Okta organization with your administrator account.\n+2. Look for the Okta URL/Okta domain in the global header of the dashboard. \n+Once located, note the Okta URL in an app such as Notepad. You'll need this URL for your next steps. \n+\n+### Configure AWS stack details\n+\n+1. Fill in the following fields on the **CloudFormation Template Specify stack details** screen using the information from your Okta application:\n+    - **Stack name** - A name of our choosing\n+    - **Or URL** Your organization's Okta URL, example: *https://companyname.okta.com*\n+    - **Client Id** - From the **Client Credentials** section of your Okta application\n+    - **Public Key Id** - Click **Add > Generate new key**. The public key is generated \n+    - **Private Key (in PEM format)** - Base64 encoded string of the PEM format of the **Private key**\n+     > [!NOTE]\n+     > You must copy all text in the field before converting to a Base64 string, including the dash before BEGIN PRIVATE KEY and after END PRIVATE KEY.\n+2. When the **CloudFormation Template Specify stack details** screen is complete, click **Next**.\n+3. On the **Configure stack options** screen, click **Next**.\n+4. Review the information you've entered, then click **Submit**.\n+5. Select the **Resources** tab, then copy the **Physical ID** (this ID is the Secret ARN) for future use.\n+\n+### Configure Okta in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Integrating Okta as an identity provider is an optional step. You can return to these steps to configure an IdP at any time. \n+\n+1. If the **Data Collectors** dashboard isn't displayed when Permissions Management launches, select **Settings** (gear icon), and then select the **Data Collectors** subtab.\n+2. On the **Data Collectors** dashboard, select **AWS**, and then select **Create Configuration**.\n+    Complete the **Manage Authorization System** steps.\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > If a Data Collector already exists in your AWS account and you want to add Okta integration, follow these steps:\n+    >  1. Select the Data Collector for which you want to add Okta integration.\n+    >  1. Click on the ellipsis next to the **Authorization System Status**.\n+    >  1. Select **Integrate Identity Provider**.\n+\n+3. On the **Integrate Identity Provider (IdP)** page, select the box for **Okta**.\n+4. Select **Launch CloudFormation Template**. The template opens in a new window.\n+   > [!NOTE]\n+   > Here you'll fill in information to create a secret Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that you'll enter on the **Integrate Identity Provider (IdP)** page. Microsoft does not read or store this ARN.\n+5. Return to the Permissions Management **Integrate Identity Provider (IdP)** page and paste the **Secret ARN** in the field provided.\n+6. Click **Next** to review and confirm the information you've entered.\n+7. Click **Verify Now & Save**.\n+   The system returns the populated AWS CloudFormation Template. \n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- For information on how to view existing roles/policies, requests, and permissions, see [View roles/policies, requests, and permission in the Remediation dashboard](ui-remediation.md)."
  },
  {
    "sha": "51b40925de84f2cd02487fdcac1618e3c8b14af0",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/how-to-configure-servicenow-application.md",
