    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,149 @@\n+---\n+title: View analytic information about groups in Permissions Management\n+description: How to view analytic information about groups in Permissions Management.\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n+\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 04/01/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+---\n+\n+# View analytic information about groups\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n+\n+The **Analytics** dashboard in Permissions Management collects detailed information, analyzes, reports on, and visualizes data about all identity types. System administrators can use the information to make informed decisions about granting permissions and reducing risk on unused permissions for:\n+\n+- **Users**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of various identities.\n+- **Groups**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members.\n+- **Active Resources**: Tracks active resources (used in the last 90 days).\n+- **Active Tasks**: Tracks active tasks (performed in the last 90 days).\n+- **Access Keys**: Tracks the permission usage of access keys for a given user.\n+- **Serverless Functions**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions.\n+\n+This article describes how to view usage analytics about groups.\n+\n+## Create a query to view groups\n+\n+When you select **Groups**, the **Usage Analytics** dashboard provides a high-level overview of groups.\n+\n+1. On the main **Analytics** dashboard, select **Groups** from the  drop-down list at the top of the screen.\n+\n+    The following components make up the **Groups** dashboard:\n+\n+    - **Authorization System Type**: Select the authorization you want to use: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud Platform (GCP).\n+    - **Authorization System**: Select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n+    - **Group Type**: Select **All**, **ED** (enterprise directory), or **Local**.\n+    - **Group Activity Status**: Select **All**, **Active**, or **Inactive**.\n+    - **Tasks Type**: Select **All**, **High Risk Tasks**, or **Delete Tasks**\n+    - **Search**: Enter group name to find specific group.\n+1. To display the criteria you've selected, select **Apply**.\n+    - **Reset Filter**: Select to discard your changes.\n+\n+\n+## View the results of your query\n+\n+The **Groups** table displays the results of your query:\n+\n+- **Group Name**: Provides the name of the group.\n+    - To view details about the group, select the down arrow.\n+- A **Group Type** icon displays to the left of the group name to describe the type of group (**ED** (enterprise directory) or **Local**).\n+- The **Domain/Account** name.\n+- The **Permission Creep Index (PCI)**: Provides the following information:\n+    - **Index**: A numeric value assigned to the PCI.\n+    - **Since**: How many days the PCI value has been at the displayed level.\n+- **Tasks**: Displays the number of **Granted** and **Executed** tasks.\n+- **Resources**: The number of resources used.\n+- **Users**: The number of users who accessed the group.\n+- Select the ellipses **(...)** and select **Tags** to add a tag.\n+\n+## Add a tag to a group\n+\n+1. Select the ellipses **(...)** and select **Tags**.\n+1. From the **Select a Tag** dropdown, select a tag.\n+1. To create a custom tag select **New Custom Tag**, add a tag name, and then select **Create**.\n+1. In the **Value (Optional)** box, enter a value.\n+1. Select the ellipses **(...)** to select **Advanced Save** options, and then select **Save**.\n+1. To add the tag to the serverless function, select **Add Tag**.\n+\n+## View detailed information about a group\n+\n+1. Select the down arrow to the left of the **Group Name**.\n+\n+    The list of **Tasks** organized by **Unused** and **Used** displays.\n+\n+1. Select the arrow to the left of the group name to view details about the task.\n+1. Select **Information** (**i**) to view when the task was last used.\n+1. From the **Tasks** dropdown, select **All Tasks**, **High Risk Tasks**, and **Delete Tasks**.\n+1. The pane on the right displays a list of **Users**, **Policies** for **AWS** and **Roles** for **GCP or AZURE**, and **Tags**.\n+\n+## Apply filters to your query\n+\n+There are many filter options within the **Groups** screen, including filters by **Authorization System Type**, **Authorization System**, **Group Type**, **Group Activity Status**, and **Tasks Type**.\n+Filters can be applied in one, two, or all three categories depending on the type of information you're looking for.\n+\n+### Apply filters by authorization system type\n+\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n+1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+### Apply filters by authorization system\n+\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select accounts from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n+1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+\n+### Apply filters by group type\n+\n+You can filter user details by type of user, user role, app, or service used, or by resource.\n+\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n+1. From the **Group Type** dropdown, select the type of user: **All**, **ED** (enterprise directory), or **Local**.\n+1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+### Apply filters by group activity status\n+\n+You can filter user details by type of user, user role, app, or service used, or by resource.\n+\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n+1. From the **Group Activity Status** dropdown, select the type of user: **All**, **Active**, or **Inactive**.\n+1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+### Apply filters by tasks type\n+\n+You can filter user details by type of user, user role, app, or service used, or by resource.\n+\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n+1. From the **Tasks Type** dropdown, select the type of user: **All**, **High Risk Tasks**, or **Delete Tasks**.\n+1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+\n+## Export the results of your query\n+\n+- To view a report of the results of your query as a comma-separated values (CSV) file, select **Export**, and then select **CSV**.\n+- To view a list of members of the groups in your query, select **Export**, and then select  **Memberships**.\n+\n+\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- To view active tasks, see [View analytic information about active tasks](usage-analytics-active-tasks.md).\n+- To view assigned permissions and usage by users, see [View analytic information about users](usage-analytics-users.md).\n+- To view active resources, see [View analytic information about active resources](usage-analytics-active-resources.md)."
  },

    "sha": "c94d92c83987434c7cd38c82db674e4030a4be6a",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/usage-analytics-home.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 46,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 46,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-home.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-home.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-home.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,46 @@\n+---\n+title: View analytic information with the Analytics dashboard in Permissions Management\n+description: How to use the Analytics dashboard in Permissions Management to view details about users, groups, active resources, active tasks, access keys, and serverless functions.\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n+\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 04/01/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+---\n+\n+# View analytic information with the Analytics dashboard\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n+\n+This article provides a brief overview of the Analytics dashboard in Permissions Management, and the type of analytic information it provides for Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud Platform (GCP).\n+\n+## Display the Analytics dashboard\n+\n+- From the Permissions Management home page, select the **Analytics** tab.\n+\n+    The **Analytics** dashboard displays detailed information about:\n+\n+    - **Users**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage by users. For more information, see [View analytic information about users](usage-analytics-users.md).\n+\n+    - **Groups**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members.  For more information, see [View analytic information about groups](usage-analytics-groups.md).\n+\n+    - **Active Resources**: Tracks resources that have been used in the last 90 days.  For more information, see [View analytic information about active resources](usage-analytics-active-resources.md).\n+\n+    - **Active Tasks**: Tracks tasks that have been performed in the last 90 days.  For more information, see [View analytic information about active tasks](usage-analytics-active-tasks.md).\n+\n+    - **Access Keys**: Tracks the permission usage of access keys for a given user.  For more information, see [View analytic information about access keys](usage-analytics-access-keys.md).\n+\n+    - **Serverless Functions**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions for AWS only.  For more information, see [View analytic information about serverless functions](usage-analytics-serverless-functions.md).\n+\n+    System administrators can use this information to make decisions about granting permissions and reducing risk on unused permissions.\n+\n+\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- To view assigned permissions and usage by users, see [View analytic information about users](usage-analytics-users.md).\n+- To view assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members, see [View analytic information about groups](usage-analytics-groups.md).\n+- To view active resources, see [View analytic information about active resources](usage-analytics-active-resources.md)."
  },
  {
    "sha": "a7c1a4ad80569048dfd611fb672990228a0d40a9",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/usage-analytics-serverless-functions.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 106,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 106,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-serverless-functions.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-serverless-functions.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-serverless-functions.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,106 @@\n+---\n+title: View analytic information about serverless functions in Permissions Management\n+description: How to view analytic information about serverless functions in Permissions Management.\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n+\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 04/01/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+---\n+\n+# View analytic information about serverless functions\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n+\n+The **Analytics** dashboard in Permissions Management collects detailed information, analyzes, reports on, and visualizes data about all identity types. System administrators can use the information to make informed decisions about granting permissions and reducing risk on unused permissions for:\n+\n+- **Users**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of various identities.\n+- **Groups**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members.\n+- **Active Resources**: Tracks active resources (used in the last 90 days).\n+- **Active Tasks**: Tracks active tasks (performed in the last 90 days).\n+- **Access Keys**: Tracks the permission usage of access keys for a given user.\n+- **Serverless Functions**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions.\n+\n+This article describes how to view usage analytics about serverless functions.\n+\n+## Create a query to view serverless functions\n+\n+When you select **Serverless Functions**, the **Analytics** dashboard provides a high-level overview of tasks used by various identities.\n+\n+1. On the main **Analytics** dashboard, select **Serverless Functions** from the  dropdown list at the top of the screen.\n+\n+    The following components make up the **Serverless Functions** dashboard:\n+\n+    - **Authorization System Type**: Select the authorization you want to use: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud Platform (GCP).\n+    - **Authorization System**: Select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n+    - **Search**: Enter criteria to find specific tasks.\n+1. Select **Apply** to display the criteria you've selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+\n+## View the results of your query\n+\n+The **Serverless Functions** table displays the results of your query.\n+\n+- **Function Name**: Provides the name of the serverless function.\n+    - To view details about a serverless function, select the down arrow to the left of the function name.\n+- A **Function Type** icon displays to the left of the function name to describe the type of serverless function, for example **Lambda function**.\n+- The **Permission Creep Index (PCI)**: Provides the following information:\n+    - **Index**: A numeric value assigned to the PCI.\n+    - **Since**: How many days the PCI value has been at the displayed level.\n+- **Tasks**: Displays the number of **Granted** and **Executed** tasks.\n+- **Resources**: The number of resources used.\n+- **Last Activity On**: The date the function was last accessed.\n+- Select the ellipses **(...)**, and then select **Tags** to add a tag.\n+\n+## Add a tag to a serverless function\n+\n+1. Select the ellipses **(...)** and select **Tags**.\n+1. From the **Select a Tag** dropdown, select a tag.\n+1. To create a custom tag select **New Custom Tag**, add a tag name, and then select **Create**.\n+1. In the **Value (Optional)** box, enter a value.\n+1. Select the ellipses **(...)** to select **Advanced Save** options, and then select **Save**.\n+1. To add the tag to the serverless function, select **Add Tag**.\n+\n+## View detailed information about a serverless function\n+\n+1. Select the down arrow to the left of the function name to display the following:\n+\n+    - A list of **Tasks** organized by **Used** and **Unused**.\n+    - **Versions**, if a version is available.\n+\n+1. Select the arrow to the left of the task name to view details about the task.\n+1. Select **Information** (**i**) to view when the task was last used.\n+1. From the **Tasks** dropdown, select **All Tasks**, **High Risk Tasks**, and **Delete Tasks**.\n+\n+\n+## Apply filters to your query\n+\n+You can filter the **Serverless Functions** results by **Authorization System Type** and **Authorization System**.\n+\n+### Apply filters by authorization system type\n+\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n+1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+\n+### Apply filters by authorization system\n+\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select accounts from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n+1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- To view active resources, see [View analytic information about active resources](usage-analytics-active-resources.md).\n+- To view the permission usage of access keys for a given user, see [View analytic information about access keys](usage-analytics-access-keys.md)."
  },
  {
    "sha": "87e3939708749108c164101c929573b5f57ca11c",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/usage-analytics-users.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 160,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 160,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-users.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-users.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-users.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,160 @@\n+---\n+title: View analytic information about users in Permissions Management\n+description: How to view analytic information about users in Permissions Management.\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n+\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 04/01/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+---\n+\n+# View analytic information about users\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n+\n+The **Analytics** dashboard in Permissions Management collects detailed information, analyzes, reports on, and visualizes data about all identity types. System administrators can use the information to make informed decisions about granting permissions and reducing risk on unused permissions for:\n+\n+- **Users**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of various identities.\n+- **Groups**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members.\n+- **Active Resources**: Tracks active resources (used in the last 90 days).\n+- **Active Tasks**: Tracks active tasks (performed in the last 90 days).\n+- **Access Keys**: Tracks the permission usage of access keys for a given user.\n+- **Serverless Functions**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions.\n+\n+This article describes how to view usage analytics about users.\n+\n+## Create a query to view users\n+\n+When you select **Users**, the **Analytics** dashboard provides a high-level overview of tasks used by various identities.\n+\n+1. On the main **Analytics** dashboard, select **Users** from the  drop-down list at the top of the screen.\n+\n+    The following components make up the **Users** dashboard:\n+\n+    - **Authorization System Type**: Select the authorization you want to use: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud Platform (GCP).\n+    - **Authorization System**: Select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders***.\n+    - **Identity Type**: Select **All** identity types, **User**, **Role/App/Service a/c** or **Resource**.\n+    - **Search**: Enter criteria to find specific tasks.\n+1. Select **Apply** to display the criteria you've selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+\n+## View the results of your query\n+\n+The **Identities** table displays the results of your query.\n+\n+- **Name**: Provides the name of the group.\n+    - To view details about the group, select the down arrow.\n+- The **Domain/Account** name.\n+- The **Permission Creep Index (PCI)**: Provides the following information:\n+    - **Index**: A numeric value assigned to the PCI.\n+    - **Since**: How many days the PCI value has been at the displayed level.\n+- **Tasks**: Displays the number of **Granted** and **Executed** tasks.\n+- **Resources**: The number of resources used.\n+- **User Groups**: The number of users who accessed the group.\n+- **Last Activity On**: The date the function was last accessed.\n+-  The ellipses **(...)**: Select **Tags** to add a tag.\n+\n+    If you're using AWS, another selection is available from the ellipses menu: **Auto Remediate**. You can use this option to remediate your results automatically.\n+\n+## Add a tag to a user\n+\n+1. Select the ellipses **(...)** and select **Tags**.\n+1. From the **Select a Tag** dropdown, select a tag.\n+1. To create a custom tag select **New Custom Tag**, add a tag name, and then select **Create**.\n+1. In the **Value (Optional)** box, enter a value.\n+1. Select the ellipses **(...)** to select **Advanced Save** options, and then select **Save**.\n+1. To add the tag to the serverless function, select **Add Tag**.\n+\n+## Set the auto-remediate option (AWS only)\n+\n+- Select the ellipses **(...)** and select **Auto Remediate**.\n+\n+    A message displays to confirm that your remediation settings are automatically updated.\n+\n+## Apply filters to your query\n+\n+There are many filter options within the **Users** screen, including filters by **Authorization System**, **Identity Type**, and **Identity State**.\n+Filters can be applied in one, two, or all three categories depending on the type of information you're looking for.\n+\n+### Apply filters by authorization system type\n+\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n+1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+\n+### Apply filters by authorization system\n+\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select accounts from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n+1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+### Apply filters by identity type\n+\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n+1. From the **Identity Type**, select the type of user: **All**, **User**, **Role/App/Service a/c**, or **Resource**.\n+1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+### Apply filters by identity subtype\n+\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n+1. From the **Identity Subtype**, select the type of user: **All**, **ED** (Enterprise Directory), **Local**, or **Cross Account**.\n+1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+### Apply filters by identity state\n+\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n+1. From the **Identity State**, select the type of user: **All**, **Active**, or **Inactive**.\n+1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+\n+### Apply filters by identity filters\n+\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n+1. From the **Identity Type**, select: **Risky** or **Incl. in PCI Calculation Only**.\n+1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+\n+### Apply filters by task type\n+\n+You can filter user details by type of user, user role, app, or service used, or by resource.\n+\n+1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n+1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n+1. From the **Task Type**, select the type of user: **All** or **High Risk Tasks**.\n+1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n+\n+    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n+\n+\n+## Export the results of your query\n+\n+- To export a report of the results of your query as a comma-separated values (CSV) file, select **Export**, and then select **CSV**.\n+- To export the data in a detailed comma-separated values (CSV) file format, select **Export** and then select **CSV (Detailed)**.\n+- To export a report of user permissions, select **Export** and then select **Permissions**.\n+\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- To view the permission usage of access keys for a given user, see [View analytic information about access keys](usage-analytics-access-keys.md).\n+- To view assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions, see [View analytic information about serverless functions](usage-analytics-serverless-functions.md)."
  },
  {
    "sha": "54300017ffddc49db86eb97cd97c779f49306469",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/whats-new-in-permissions-management.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 101,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 101,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fwhats-new-in-permissions-management.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fwhats-new-in-permissions-management.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fwhats-new-in-permissions-management.md?ref=fb74d47ded7bba616bb6ab5256a7eb80eaf74273",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,101 @@\n+---\n+title: What's new in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management\n+description: View the latest public preview and general availability of features in Permissions Management.\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n+\n+ms.topic: whats-new\n+ms.date: 04/01/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+---\n+\n+# What's new in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n+\n+This article provides the latest Public Preview and General Availability information of features in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management. \n+\n+## May 2024\n+\n+### General availability - Microsoft Entra Permissions Management integration for Microsoft Defender for Cloud\n+**Type:** Changed feature   \n+**Service category:**                      \n+**Product capability:** Permissions Management  \n+\n+Deploying applications and infrastructure across multiple clouds has become the norm. Ensuring the security of cloud applications and infrastructure requires integrating identity and permission insights into the overall security strategy. This objective is achieved through the integration of Microsoft Entra Permissions Management with Microsoft Defender for Cloud. \n+\n+Permissions Management capabilities are available to integrate into the Defender for Cloud CSPM plan. Adding the capabilities of [Permissions Management to Defender for Cloud](permissions-management-for-defender-for-cloud.md) strengthens the prevention of security breaches that might occur due to excessive permissions or misconfigurations in the cloud environment. By continuously monitoring and managing cloud entitlements, Permissions Management helps to reduce the attack surface, detect potential threats, and maintain compliance with regulatory standards. These added features make Permissions Management an essential tool to integrate into the capabilities of Defender for Cloud for securing cloud-native applications and protecting sensitive data in the cloud. \n+\n+For instructions on how to enable Permissions Management in your Defender for Cloud environment, see [Enable Permissions Management in Microsoft Defender for Cloud](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2252561)\n+\n+\n+### General availability - Support for PIM-enabled Groups \n+**Type:** Changed feature   \n+**Service category:**                      \n+**Product capability:** Permissions Management  \n+\n+Privileged Identity Management (PIM) for Groups in Microsoft Entra ID allows Permissions Management admins to grant users just-in-time membership and ownership of a security group or a Microsoft 365 group. Nested groups are also supported. For example, if a user is an active member of Group A, and Group A is an eligible member of Group B, the user can activate their membership in Group B. PIM provides a powerful mechanism to manage access and enhance security by granting just-in-time access to critical resources. \n+\n+Microsoft Entra Permissions Management adds the support to read the just-in-time membership along with existing support for direct group membership. It also solves the challenge of having visibility into who has access to what resource with eligible and direct role assignments. This feature enables the complete visibility into RBAC permissions assigned to the identities in different ways and the potential impact on Permissions Creep Index (PCI). A complete list of RBAC role assignments is provisioned directly, via the group membership or by an eligible group member, and can be seen per identity under the Analytics tab. \n+\n+## March 2024\n+\n+### Public Preview - Support for PIM-enabled Groups \n+**Type:** Changed feature   \n+**Service category:**                      \n+**Product capability:** Permissions Management  \n+\n+As multiple customers embrace PIM for groups as a popular feature, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management adds the support to read the just-in-time membership impact on the eligible granted Azure RBAC permissions and Permissions Creep Index (PCI). The feature enables the complete visibility into RBAC permissions assigned to the identities in different ways.  \n+ \n+In the Permissions Management console, admins can see the membership eligibility status as well as role eligibility status for Groups. For each identity, admins can get the visibility into the membership eligibility status as well as roles eligibility status. \n+\n+\n+## December 2023\n+\n+### General availability - Permissions Analytics Report PDF\n+\n+**Type:** Changed feature   \n+**Service category:**                      \n+**Product capability:** Permissions Management  \n+\n+The [Permissions Analytics Report (PAR)](product-permissions-analytics-reports.md) lists findings relating to permissions risks across identities and resources in Permissions Management. The PAR is an integral part of the risk assessment process where customers discover areas of highest risk in their cloud infrastructure. This report can be directly viewed in the Permissions Management UI, downloaded in Excel (XSLX) format, and exported as a PDF. The report is available for all supported cloud environments: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud Platform (GCP). \n+\n+The PAR PDF is one part of the overall reporting redesign effort led by the engineering team. As part of this feature release, customers can download all reports (system or custom) with no row limitations in CSV and XSLX formats. \n+\n+\n+## October 2023\n+\n+### Public preview - Permissions Analytics Report PDF for multiple authorization systems\n+\n+**Type:** Changed feature   \n+**Service category:**                        \n+**Product capability:** Permissions Management            \n+\n+The Permissions Analytics Report (PAR) lists findings relating to permissions risks across identities and resources in Permissions Management. The PAR is an integral part of the risk assessment process where customers discover areas of highest risk in their cloud infrastructure. This report can be directly viewed in the Permissions Management UI, downloaded in Excel (XSLX) format, and exported as a PDF. The report is available for all supported cloud environments: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud Platform (GCP).  \n+\n+The PAR PDF has a new design to enhance usability, align with the product UX redesign effort, and address various customer feature requests. [You can download the PAR PDF for up to 10 authorization systems](product-permissions-analytics-reports.md).\n+\n+### General availability - ServiceNow app for Permissions Management\n+\n+**Type:** New feature   \n+**Service category:**                        \n+**Product capability:** Permissions Management\n+\n+The ServiceNow Application for Microsoft Entra Permissions Management enables users to request time-bound, on-demand permissions for multicloud environments (Azure, AWS, GCP) through the ServiceNow portal. This integration aids organizations in enhancing their Zero Trust posture by enforcing the principle of least privilege for multicloud permissions. The ServiceNow app streamlines access permission requests within existing approval workflows.  \n+\n+Get the ServiceNow app in the [ServiceNow app store](https://store.servicenow.com/sn_appstore_store.do#!/store/application/24073ae31bfca9100e564082b24bcb56/1.0.1?referer=%2Fstore%2Fsearch%3Flistingtype%3Dallintegrations%25253Bancillary_app%25253Bcertified_apps%25253Bcontent%25253Bindustry_solution%25253Boem%25253Butility%25253Btemplate%25253Bgenerative_ai%25253Bsnow_solution%26q%3Dentra%2520permissions%2520management&sl=sh). \n+\n+### Public preview - Okta and AWS Identity Center identity provider integrations\n+\n+**Type:** New feature   \n+**Service category:**                        \n+**Product capability:** Permissions Management\n+\n+Permissions Management supports third party identity providers (IdP) integration to get more insight of single sign-on data of permissions assigned in cloud environments. With this information, Permissions Management can provide more accurate analytics. By reading role assignments and user data from the IdP side, Permissions Management more effectively calculates permissions granted, and as a result, reads more precise data on permissions creep. \n+\n+For [Okta Identity Provider integration](how-to-configure-okta-as-an-identity-provider.md), an admin needs to configure the API application to give the access to read Okta users, groups, and apps via Okta APIs. Permissions Management reads Okta users, groups, and apps via Okta APIs. \n+\n+For [AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) Identity Center integration](how-to-configure-aws-iam.md), an admin can provide Permissions Management access to read user and role access configuration data from the management account by running the CloudFormation template (CFT) in their AWS environment. After successful configuration, Permissions Management can read the data to calculate the analytics.\n+"
  }
]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response: This commit primarily updates documentation related to Microsoft Entra Permissions Management. Key changes include the removal of numerous old redirection rules from `.openpublishing.redirection.json`, the addition of new articles covering error codes, FAQs, onboarding procedures for AWS, Azure, and GCP, role/policy management, and troubleshooting. Additionally, there are updates to existing files to reflect new roles like 'Dragon Administrator' and 'Teams Reader', and an improved 'What's New' section for role-based access control. Several image files have also been added, likely to support the newly introduced or updated articles.

{"role":"user","content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: [
  {
    "sha": "c74b96e5e90cdb74aa9faa8523760b21c8214a2f",
    "filename": "docs/identity/role-based-access-control/includes/teams-reader.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 16,
    "deletions": 1,
    "changes": 17,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5220da96294b406aab41aeec1fd843131f2db91f/docs%2Fidentity%2Frole-based-access-control%2Fincludes%2Fteams-reader.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5220da96294b406aab41aeec1fd843131f2db91f/docs%2Fidentity%2Frole-based-access-control%2Fincludes%2Fteams-reader.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Frole-based-access-control%2Fincludes%2Fteams-reader.md?ref=5220da96294b406aab41aeec1fd843131f2db91f",
    "patch": "@@ -4,10 +4,25 @@ description: Teams Reader\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: role-based-access-control\n ms.topic: include\n-ms.date: 07/09/2025\n+ms.date: 10/02/2025\n ms.custom: include file\n ---\n \n+Assign the Teams Reader role to users who need to do the following tasks: \n+\n+- Read settings and administrative information in the Teams admin center, but not perform any management actions\n+- Read the Microsoft Call Quality Dashboard (CQD), but not access any troubleshooting capabilities\n+\n+Users with this role **cannot** do the following tasks:\n+\n+- Cannot view Teams management\n+- Cannot access Meetings & Calls details of users\n+- Cannot access Notifications & Rules management\n+- Cannot access Frontline worker deployment management\n+- Cannot access the advanced collaboration insights dashboard\n+\n+[Learn more](/microsoftteams/using-admin-roles)\n+\n <!-- autogenerated content starts here -->\n \n > [!div class=\"mx-tableFixed\"]"
  },
  {
    "sha": "e72facbf5a1cd5ff81d7fb92f4cee200287cfa04",
    "filename": "docs/identity/role-based-access-control/whats-new.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 1,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 1,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5220da96294b406aab41aeec1fd843131f2db91f/docs%2Fidentity%2Frole-based-access-control%2Fwhats-new.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5220da96294b406aab41aeec1fd843131f2db91f/docs%2Fidentity%2Frole-based-access-control%2Fwhats-new.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Frole-based-access-control%2Fwhats-new.md?ref=5220da96294b406aab41aeec1fd843131f2db91f",
    "patch": "@@ -21,6 +21,7 @@ This article provides information about new features and documentation improveme\n | Date | Area | Description |\n | --- | --- | --- |\n | Oct 2025 | Roles | Added [Dragon Administrator](permissions-reference.md#dragon-administrator) role. |\n+| August 2025 | Roles | Added [Teams Reader](permissions-reference.md#teams-reader) role. |\n | June 2025 | Roles | Added [Organizational Data Source Administrator](permissions-reference.md#organizational-data-source-administrator) role. |\n | June 2025 | Administrative units | General availability of restricted management administrative units. See [Restricted management administrative units in Microsoft Entra ID](admin-units-restricted-management.md). |\n | May 2025 | Roles | Updated permissions for multiple roles. See [Microsoft Entra built-in roles](permissions-reference.md). |"
  }
]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response: The recent commit introduces documentation for the **Teams Reader role** within Microsoft Entra ID's role-based access control. This role grants users the ability to view settings and read data in the Teams admin centre and Call Quality Dashboard without making management changes. Additionally, a `whats-new.md` file has been updated to reflect the addition of the Teams Reader role in August 2025.

  },
  {
    "sha": "e9f1ab995c5a9a4b3dc9ec20271da82a5e438be0",
    "filename": "docs/external-id/cross-tenant-access-settings-b2b-collaboration.yml",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 1,
    "deletions": 1,
    "changes": 2,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/1a8d43ddf11c743af805d2545670f3cb0b5fda64/docs%2Fexternal-id%2Fcross-tenant-access-settings-b2b-collaboration.yml",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/1a8d43ddf11c743af805d2545670f3cb0b5fda64/docs%2Fexternal-id%2Fcross-tenant-access-settings-b2b-collaboration.yml",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fexternal-id%2Fcross-tenant-access-settings-b2b-collaboration.yml?ref=1a8d43ddf11c743af805d2545670f3cb0b5fda64",
    "patch": "@@ -342,7 +342,7 @@ procedureSection:\n \n           - **Trust multifactor authentication from Microsoft Entra tenants**: Select this checkbox to allow your Conditional Access policies to trust MFA claims from external organizations. During authentication, Microsoft Entra ID checks a user's credentials for a claim that the user completed MFA. If not, an MFA challenge is initiated in the user's home tenant. This setting isn't applied if an external user signs in using [granular delegated admin privileges (GDAP)](/partner-center/customers/gdap-introduction), such as used by a technician at a Cloud Service Provider that administers services in your tenant. When an external user signs in using GDAP, MFA is always required in the user's home tenant, and always trusted in the resource tenant. MFA registration of a GDAP user isn't supported outside of the user's home tenant. If your organization has a requirement to disallow access to service provider technicians based on MFA in the user's home tenant, you can remove the GDAP relationship in [Microsoft 365 admin center](https://admin.microsoft.com/Adminportal/Home#/partners).\n \n-          - **Trust compliant devices**: Allows your Conditional Access policies to trust [compliant device claims](~/identity/conditional-access/policy-alt-all-users-compliant-hybrid-or-mfa.md) from an external organization when their users access your resources.\n+          - **Trust compliant devices**: Allows your Conditional Access policies to trust [compliant device claims](~/identity/conditional-access/policy-all-users-device-compliance.md) from an external organization when their users access your resources.\n \n           - **Trust Microsoft Entra hybrid joined devices**: Allows your Conditional Access policies to trust Microsoft Entra hybrid joined device claims from an external organization when their users access your resources.\n "

    "patch": "@@ -6,7 +6,7 @@ author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n manager: dougeby\n ms.reviewer: lhuangnorth\n \n-ms.date: 09/30/2025\n+ms.date: 10/01/2025\n \n ms.update-cycle: 180-days\n ms.service: entra-id\n@@ -151,13 +151,13 @@ There are several key points to consider regarding the identity and permissions\n \n ### ServiceNow integration\n \n-Organizations that use the [ServiceNow plugin for Security Copilot](/copilot/security/plugin-servicenow) can now have the Conditional Access optimization agent create ServiceNow incidents for each new suggestion the agent generates. This allows IT and security teams to track, review, and approve or reject agent suggestions within existing ServiceNow workflows. At this time, only change requests (CHG) are supported.\n+Organizations that use the [ServiceNow plugin for Security Copilot](/copilot/security/plugin-servicenow) can now have the Conditional Access optimization agent create ServiceNow change requests for each new suggestion the agent generates. This allows IT and security teams to track, review, and approve or reject agent suggestions within existing ServiceNow workflows. At this time, only change requests (CHG) are supported.\n \n To use the ServiceNow integration, your organization must have the [ServiceNow plugin](/copilot/security/plugin-servicenow) configured.\n \n :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization/agent-service-now-integration-setting.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the ServiceNow integration settings.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization/agent-service-now-integration-setting.png\":::\n \n-When the ServiceNow plugin is turned on in the Conditional Access optimization agent settings, each new suggestion from the agent creates a ServiceNow incident. The incident includes details about the suggestion, such as the type of policy, the users or groups affected, and the rationale behind the recommendation. The integration also provides a feedback loop: The agent monitors the state of the ServiceNow incident and can automatically implement the change when the incident is approved.\n+When the ServiceNow plugin is turned on in the Conditional Access optimization agent settings, each new suggestion from the agent creates a ServiceNow change request. The change request includes details about the suggestion, such as the type of policy, the users or groups affected, and the rationale behind the recommendation. The integration also provides a feedback loop: The agent monitors the state of the ServiceNow change request and can automatically implement the change when the change request is approved.\n \n :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization/agent-service-now-integration-ticket.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the ServiceNow integration within an agent suggestion.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization/agent-service-now-integration-ticket.png\":::\n "

    "patch": "@@ -4,7 +4,7 @@ description: Plan your Conditional Access policies to balance security and produ\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: conditional-access\n ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 09/05/2025\n+ms.date: 09/29/2025\n ms.author: gasinh\n author: gargi-sinha\n manager: martinco\n@@ -18,31 +18,31 @@ ms.custom:\n ---\n # Plan a Conditional Access deployment\n \n-Planning your Conditional Access deployment is critical to achieving your organization's access strategy for apps and resources. Conditional Access policies provide significant configuration flexibility. However, this flexibility means you need to plan carefully to avoid undesirable results.\n \n [Microsoft Entra Conditional Access](overview.md) combines signals like user, device, and location to automate decisions and enforce organizational access policies for resources. These Conditional Access policies help you balance security and productivity by enforcing security controls when needed and staying out of the user’s way when they aren't.\n \n Conditional Access forms the basis of [Microsoft’s Zero Trust security policy engine](https://www.microsoft.com/security/business/zero-trust).\n \n ![Diagram showing a high level Conditional Access overview.](./media/plan-conditional-access/conditional-access-overview-how-it-works.png)\n \n-Microsoft provides [security defaults](~/fundamentals/security-defaults.md) that ensure a basic level of security for tenants that don't have Microsoft Entra ID P1 or P2. With Conditional Access, you can create policies that give the same protection as security defaults, but with more granularity. With Conditional Access, you can create policies that give the same protection as security defaults, but with more granularity. Conditional Access and security defaults aren't meant to be combined because creating Conditional Access policies prevents you from enabling security defaults.\n \n ## Prerequisites\n \n - A working Microsoft Entra tenant with Microsoft Entra ID P1, P2, or a trial license enabled.     "patch": "@@ -1,11 +1,11 @@\n ---\n-title: Enforce device compliance with Conditional Access\n-description: Require devices accessing resources be marked as compliant with your organization's configuration policies.\n+title: How to Require Device Compliance with Conditional Access\n+description: \"Learn how to enforce device compliance with Conditional Access policies. Ensure secure access to resources by meeting your organization's configuration requirements.\"\n \n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: conditional-access\n ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 06/24/2025\n+ms.date: 10/01/2025\n \n ms.author: joflore\n author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n@@ -14,11 +14,11 @@ ms.reviewer: jodah\n ---\n # Require device compliance with Conditional Access\n \n-Microsoft Intune and Microsoft Entra work together to secure your organization through [device compliance policies](/mem/intune/protect/device-compliance-get-started) and Conditional Access. Device compliance policies are a great way to ensure user devices meet minimum configuration requirements. The requirements can be enforced when users access services protected with Conditional Access policies.\n+Microsoft Intune and Microsoft Entra work together to secure your organization through [device compliance policies](/mem/intune/protect/device-compliance-get-started) and Conditional Access. Device compliance policies ensure user devices meet minimum configuration requirements. The requirements can be enforced when users access services protected with Conditional Access policies.\n \n Some organizations might not be ready to require device compliance for all users. These organizations might instead choose to deploy the following policies: \n \n-- [Require compliant or Microsoft Entra hybrid joined device for their administrators](policy-alt-admin-device-compliand-hybrid.md)\n+- [Require a compliant or Microsoft Entra hybrid joined device for administrators](policy-alt-admin-device-compliand-hybrid.md)\n - [Require a compliant device, Microsoft Entra hybrid joined device, **OR** multifactor authentication for all users](policy-alt-all-users-compliant-hybrid-or-mfa.md)\n - [Block unknown or unsupported device platforms](policy-all-users-device-unknown-unsupported.md)\n - [Disable browser persistence](policy-all-users-persistent-browser.md)\n@@ -63,11 +63,16 @@ The following steps help create a Conditional Access policy to require devices a\n \n On iOS, Android, macOS, and some non-Microsoft web browsers, Microsoft Entra ID identifies the device using a client certificate that is provisioned when the device is registered with Microsoft Entra ID. When a user first signs in through the browser the user is prompted to select the certificate. The end user must select this certificate before they can continue to use the browser.\n \n-#### Subscription activation\n+### B2B scenarios\n+\n+For organizations you have a relationship with and trust, you might trust their device compliance claims. To configure this setting, see the article [Manage cross-tenant access settings for B2B collaboration](../../external-id/cross-tenant-access-settings-b2b-collaboration.yml#to-change-inbound-trust-settings-for-mfa-and-device-claims).\n+\n+### Subscription activation\n \n Organizations that use the [Subscription Activation](/windows/deployment/windows-10-subscription-activation) feature to enable users to \"step-up\" from one version of Windows to another, might want to exclude the Windows Store for Business, AppID 45a330b1-b1ec-4cc1-9161-9f03992aa49f from their device compliance policy.\n \n ## Related content\n \n-- [Create a compliance policy in Microsoft Intune](/mem/intune/protect/create-compliance-policy)\n-- [Conditional Access grant controls](/entra/identity/conditional-access/concept-conditional-access-grant#require-device-to-be-marked-as-compliant)\n+- Learn how to [create a compliance policy in Microsoft Intune](/mem/intune/protect/create-compliance-policy).\n+- Learn about [Conditional Access grant controls](/entra/identity/conditional-access/concept-conditional-access-grant#require-device-to-be-marked-as-compliant).\n+- Learn how to [configure cross-tenant access settings](/entra/external-id/cross-tenant-access-settings-b2b-collaboration#to-change-inbound-trust-settings-for-mfa-and-device-claims)."

    "patch": "@@ -1,11 +1,11 @@\n ---\n title: Sign-in risk-based multifactor authentication\n-description: Create Conditional Access policies using Microsoft Entra ID Protection sign-in risk.\n+description: Protect your organization by implementing Conditional Access policies that address sign-in risks using Microsoft Entra ID Protection.\n \n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: conditional-access\n ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n+ms.date: 10/01/2025\n \n ms.author: joflore\n author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n@@ -14,11 +14,11 @@ ms.reviewer: lhuangnorth, cokoopma\n ---\n # Require multifactor authentication for elevated sign-in risk\n \n-Most users have a normal behavior that can be tracked, when they fall outside of this norm it could be risky to allow them to just sign in. You might want to block that user or maybe ask them to perform multifactor authentication to prove that they're really who they say they are. \n+Most users have normal behavior that can be tracked. When their behavior falls outside this norm, it might be risky to let them sign in. You might want to block the user or ask them to complete multifactor authentication to confirm their identity. \n \n-A sign-in risk represents the probability that a given authentication request isn't the identity owner. Organizations with Microsoft Entra ID P2 licenses can create Conditional Access policies incorporating [Microsoft Entra ID Protection sign-in risk detections](~/id-protection/concept-identity-protection-risks.md). \n+Sign-in risk represents the likelihood that an authentication request isn't from the identity owner. Organizations with Microsoft Entra ID P2 licenses can create Conditional Access policies incorporating [Microsoft Entra ID Protection sign-in risk detections](~/id-protection/concept-identity-protection-risks.md). \n \n-The Sign-in risk-based policy protects users from registering MFA in risky sessions. If users aren't registered for MFA, their risky sign-ins are blocked, and they see an AADSTS53004 error.\n+The sign-in risk-based policy prevents users from registering MFA during risky sessions. If users aren't registered for MFA, their risky sign-ins are blocked, and they receive an AADSTS53004 error.\n \n ## User exclusions\n [!INCLUDE [active-directory-policy-exclusions](~/includes/entra-policy-exclude-user.md)]\n@@ -37,3 +37,4 @@ The Sign-in risk-based policy protects users from registering MFA in risky sessi\n - [User risk-based Conditional Access](policy-risk-based-user.md)\n - [Determine effect using Conditional Access report-only mode](howto-conditional-access-insights-reporting.md)\n - [Use report-only mode for Conditional Access to determine the results of new policy decisions](concept-conditional-access-report-only.md)\n+- [Configure cross-tenant access settings](/entra/external-id/cross-tenant-access-settings-b2b-collaboration#to-change-inbound-trust-settings-for-mfa-and-device-claims)"

Organizations with Microsoft Entra ID P2 licenses can create Conditional Access policies incorporating [Microsoft Entra ID Protection user risk detections](~/id-protection/concept-identity-protection-risks.md). \n+Microsoft works with researchers, law enforcement, security teams at Microsoft, and other trusted sources to find leaked username and password pairs.     "sha": "4048ed07c233479a8b7e03918a392aa8b3baf11e",
    "filename": "docs/identity/domain-services/synchronization.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 1,
    "deletions": 1,
    "changes": 2,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/1a8d43ddf11c743af805d2545670f3cb0b5fda64/docs%2Fidentity%2Fdomain-services%2Fsynchronization.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/1a8d43ddf11c743af805d2545670f3cb0b5fda64/docs%2Fidentity%2Fdomain-services%2Fsynchronization.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fdomain-services%2Fsynchronization.md?ref=1a8d43ddf11c743af805d2545670f3cb0b5fda64",
    "patch": "@@ -14,7 +14,7 @@ ms.author: justinha\n ---\n # How objects and credentials are synchronized in a Microsoft Entra Domain Services managed domain\n \n-Objects and credentials in a Microsoft Entra Domain Services managed domain can either be created locally within the domain, or synchronized from a Microsoft Entra tenant. When you first deploy Domain Services, an automatic one-way synchronization is configured and started to replicate the objects from Microsoft Entra ID. This one-way synchronization continues to run in the background to keep the  Domain Services managed domain up-to-date with any changes from Microsoft Entra ID. No synchronization occurs from Domain Services back to Microsoft Entra ID.\n+Objects and credentials in a Microsoft Entra Domain Services managed domain can either be created locally within the domain, or synchronized from a Microsoft Entra tenant. When you first deploy Domain Services, an automatic one-way synchronization is configured and started to replicate the objects from Microsoft Entra ID. This one-way synchronization continues to run in the background to keep the Domain Services managed domain up-to-date with any changes from Microsoft Entra ID. No synchronization occurs from Domain Services back to Microsoft Entra ID.\n \n In a hybrid environment, objects and credentials from an on-premises AD DS domain can be synchronized to Microsoft Entra ID using Microsoft Entra Connect. Once those objects are successfully synchronized to Microsoft Entra ID, the automatic background sync then makes those objects and credentials available to applications using the managed domain.\n "

    "patch": "@@ -160,7 +160,7 @@ To authenticate users on the managed domain, Domain Services needs password hash\n >\n > Synchronized credential information in Microsoft Entra ID can't be re-used if you later create a managed domain - you must reconfigure the password hash synchronization to store the password hashes again. Previously domain-joined VMs or users won't be able to immediately authenticate - Microsoft Entra ID needs to generate and store the password hashes in the new managed domain.\n >\n-> [Microsoft Entra Connect cloud sync is not supported with Domain Services](/azure/active-directory/hybrid/cloud-sync/what-is-cloud-sync#comparison-between-azure-ad-connect-and-cloud-sync). On-premises users need to be synced using Microsoft Entra Connect in order to be able to access domain-joined VMs. For more information, see [Password hash sync process for Domain Services and Microsoft Entra Connect][password-hash-sync-process].\n+> [Microsoft Entra Cloud sync isn't supported with Domain Services](/azure/active-directory/hybrid/cloud-sync/what-is-cloud-sync#comparison-between-azure-ad-connect-and-cloud-sync). On-premises users need to be synced using Microsoft Entra Connect sync in order to be able to access domain-joined VMs. Connect sync must be installed on Windows Server 2022, Windows Server 2019, or Windows Server 2016. For more information, see [Password hash sync process for Domain Services and Microsoft Entra Connect][password-hash-sync-process].\n \n The steps to generate and store these password hashes are different for cloud-only user accounts created in Microsoft Entra ID versus user accounts that are synchronized from your on-premises directory using Microsoft Entra Connect.\n "
  },

    "patch": "@@ -1,58 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: View a list and description of all system reports available in Permissions Management reports\n-description: View a list and description of all system reports available in Permissions Management.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-\n-# View a list and description of system reports\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire). \n-\n-Microsoft Entra Permissions Management has various types of system reports that capture specific sets of data. These reports allow management, auditors, and administrators to:\n-\n-- Make timely decisions.\n-- Analyze trends and system/user performance.\n-- Identify trends in data and high risk areas so that management can address issues more quickly and improve their efficiency.\n-\n-This article provides you with a list and description of the system reports available in Permissions Management. Depending on the report, you can download it in comma-separated values (**CSV**) format, portable document format (**PDF**), or Microsoft Excel Open XML Spreadsheet (**XLSX**) format.\n-\n-## Download a system report\n-\n-1. In the Permissions Management home page, select the **Reports** tab, and then select the **Systems Reports** subtab.\n-1. In the **Report Name** column, find the report you want, and then select the down arrow to the right of the report name to download the report.\n-\n-    Or, from the ellipses **(...)** menu, select **Download**.\n-\n-    The following message displays: **Successfully Started To Generate On Demand Report.**\n-\n-\n-## Summary of available system reports\n-\n-| Report name                | Type of the report                | File format              | Description               | Availability                | Collated report?                 |\n-|----------------------------|-----------------------------------|--------------------------|---------------------------| ----------------------------|----------------------------------|\n-| Access Key Entitlements and Usage Report                | Summary </p>Detailed                | CSV                 | This report displays: </p> - Access key age, last rotation date, and last usage date availability in the summary report. Use this report to decide when to rotate access keys. </p> - Granted task and Permissions creep index (PCI) score. This report provides supporting information when you want to take the action on the keys.                | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP                 | Yes      |\n-| All Permissions for Identity                 | Summary                 | CSV                | This report lists all the assigned permissions for the selected identities.                | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP            | N/A      |\n-| Group Entitlements and Usage       | Summary                | CSV                | This report tracks all group level entitlements and the permission assignment, PCI. The number of members is also listed as part of this report.                 | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP                 | Yes      |\n-| Identity Permissions                 | Summary                | CSV                 | This report tracks any, or specific, task usage per **User**, **Group**, **Role**, or **App**.                 | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP                 | N/A      |\n-| AWS Role Policy Audit       | Detailed | CSV | This report gives the list of AWS roles, which can be assumed by **User**, **Group**, **resource** or **AWS Role**.                | AWS | N/A      |\n-| Cross Account Access Details| Detailed                 | CSV                 | This report helps track **User**, **Group** from other AWS accounts have cross account access to the specified AWS account.                | AWS                | N/A      |\n-| PCI History                 | Summary                 | CSV                 | This report helps track **Monthly PCI History** for each authorized system. It can be used to plot the trend of the PCI.                 | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP                 | Yes      |\n-| Permissions Analytics Report (PAR)  |     Detailed                 | XSLX, PDF                 | This report lists the different key findings in the selected authorized systems. The key findings include **Super identities**, **Inactive identities**, **Over-provisioned active identities**, **Storage bucket hygiene**, **Access key age (AWS)**, and so on. </p>This report helps administrators to visualize the findings across the organization and make decisions.                    | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP                | Yes for XSLX     |\n-| Role/Policy Details                 | Summary                 | CSV                | This report captures **Assigned/Unassigned** and **Custom/system policy with used/unused condition** for specific or all AWS accounts. </p>Similar data can be captured for Azure and GCP for assigned and unassigned roles.                | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP                 | No      |\n-| User Entitlements and Usage     | Detailed <p>Summary <p> Permissions                | CSV                 | **Summary** This report provides the summary view of all the identities with Permissions Creep Index (PCI), granted and executed tasks per Azure subscription, AWS account, GCP project.     </p>**Detailed** This report provides a detailed view of Azure role assignments, GCP role assignments and AWS policy assignment along with Permissions Creep Index (PCI), tasks used by each identity. </p>**Permissions** This report provides the list of role assignments for Azure, GCP and policy assignments in AWS per identity.                 | AWS</p>Azure</p>GCP                | Yes      |\n-\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- For information on how to view system reports in the **Reports** dashboard, see [View system reports in the Reports dashboard](product-reports.md).\n-- For information about how to create, view, and share a system report, see [Create, view, and share a custom report](report-view-system-report.md).\n-- For information about how to create and view a custom report, see [Generate and view a custom report](report-create-custom-report.md).\n-- For information about how to create and view the Permissions analytics report, see [Generate and download the Permissions analytics report](product-permissions-analytics-reports.md)."

    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Ferror-codes-onboarding.md?ref=f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd",
    "patch": "@@ -1,105 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: Error codes when onboarding Permissions Management\n-description: Understand potential error codes that may appear during onboarding of Microsoft Entra Permissions Management\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: reference\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# Error codes: Microsoft Entra Permissions Management \n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-During onboarding, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management may return error messages that an admin can triage. This article lists data collection error messages and their descriptions shown in the Permissions Management UI, along with proposed solutions.\n-\n-\n-## AWS_ACCESSADVISOR_COLLECTION_ERROR \n-\n-This account does not have permissions to view ```Service Last Accessed```. \n-\n-### Proposed solution\n-\n-- Verify that you're signed in using Management Account credentials. The AWS account must have a policy that has permissions to generate, get, or list ```ServiceLastAccessDetails``` or equivalent permissions. \n-- In the AWS Management Console, verify that Service Control Policies (SCPs) are enabled in your organization root.\n-\n-## AWS_CLOUDTRAIL_DISABLED\n-\n-The AWS environment doesn't have CloudTrail configured, or you don't have permissions to access CloudTrail.\n-\n-### Proposed solution\n-\n-CloudTrail is automatically created when an AWS account is created. \n-\n-To access:\n-- Verify you're signed in using Management Account credentials.\n-- Enable CloudTrail as a trusted service in your AWS organization.\n-- Ensure that the AWS account has the CloudTrail managed policies ```AWSCloudTrail_FullAccess```, ```AWSCloudTrail_ReadOnlyAccess```, or is granted equivalent permissions.\n-\n-## AWS_CLOUDTRAIL_S3_ACCESS_DENIED \n-\n-This account doesn't have permissions to access S3 Bucket CloudTrail logs. \n-\n-### Proposed solution\n-\n-Steps to try:\n-- Verify you're signed in using Management Account credentials.\n-- Enable CloudTrail as a trusted service in your AWS organization.\n-- The AWS account must have the CloudTrail managed policy ```AWSCloudTrail_FullAccess``` or have been granted equivalent permissions.\n-- For cross-account access, each account must have an IAM role with an access policy that grants access.\n-- CloudTrail must have the required permissions to deliver log files to the S3 bucket and S3 bucket policies are updated to receive and store log files.\n-\n-## AWS_LDAP_CREDENTIALS_INVALID \n-\n-Invalid LDAP Credentials. \n-\n-### Proposed Solution\n-\n-Verify that the hard drive on your domain controller is not full.\n-\n-\n-## AWS_LDAP_UNREACHABLE \n-\n-Connection failure while trying to access LDAP service. \n-\n-\n-### Proposed solution\n-\n-This issue is common with the AWS Managed Microsoft AD Connector used to enable LDAPS. Verify if the AD connector can communicate via TCP and UDP over the 88 (Kerberos) and 389 (LDAP) ports.\n-\n-## AWS_SYSTEM_ROLE_POLICIES_COLLECTION_ERROR \n-\n-Error during the collection of System role policies.\n-\n-### Proposed solution\n-\n-If your system role policies include Service Control Policies (SCPs), verify you're signed in using Management Account credentials. The AWS account must have the required permissions to display the policies’ details and attached entities.\n-\n-\n-## ERROR_GCP_PROJECT_MIN_PERMISSION\n-\n-Insufficient Project permissions. \n-\n-### Proposed solution\n-\n-Verify you have been granted the correct IAM roles or roles with equivalent permissions that grant access to the project: *Organization Admin*, *Security Admin*, or *Project IAM Admin*.\n-\n-\n-## ERROR_NO_IDENTIFIER_URIS_IN_APP\n-\n-No Identifier URIs configured for app. \n-\n-### Proposed solution\n-\n-- Verify the application configuration for the configured Identifier URI’s in the portal. \n-- Check the Microsoft Entra application’s manifest file. \n-\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- For information on how to onboard an Amazon Web Services (AWS) account, see [Onboard an Amazon Web Services (AWS) account](onboard-aws.md).\n-- For information on how to onboard an account after initial onboarding, see [Add an account/subscription/project after onboarding](onboard-add-account-after-onboarding.md)"
  },
