From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Service Resource Type**, select the type of service resource.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-## Export the results of your query\n-\n-- To view a report of the results of your query as a comma-separated values (CSV) file, select **Export**, and then select **CSV**.\n-\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- To track the permission usage of access keys for a given user, see [View usage analytics about access keys](usage-analytics-access-keys.md).\n-- To track assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions, see [View usage analytics about serverless functions](usage-analytics-serverless-functions.md)."
  },

    "patch": "@@ -1,106 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: View analytic information about active tasks in Permissions Management\n-description: How to view analytic information about active tasks in Permissions Management.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# View analytic information about active tasks\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-The **Analytics** dashboard in Permissions Management collects detailed information, analyzes, reports on, and visualizes data about all identity types. System administrators can use the information to make informed decisions about granting permissions and reducing risk on unused permissions for:\n-\n-- **Users**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of various identities.\n-- **Groups**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members.\n-- **Active Resources**: Tracks active resources (used in the last 90 days).\n-- **Active Tasks**: Tracks active tasks (performed in the last 90 days).\n-- **Access Keys**: Tracks the permission usage of access keys for a given user.\n-- **Serverless Functions**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions.\n-\n-This article describes how to view usage analytics about active tasks.\n-\n-## Create a query to view active tasks\n-\n-When you select **Active Tasks**, the **Analytics** dashboard provides a high-level overview of tasks used by various identities.\n-\n-1. On the main **Analytics** dashboard, select **Active Tasks** from the  drop-down list at the top of the screen.\n-\n-    The dashboard only lists tasks that are active. The following components make up the **Active Tasks** dashboard:\n-\n-    - **Authorization System Type**: Select the authorization you want to use: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud Platform (GCP).\n-    - **Authorization System**: Select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-      > [!NOTE]\n-      > Folders can be used to organize and group together your list of accounts, or subscriptions. To create a folder, go to **Settings (gear icon) > Folders > Create Folder**.\n-    - **Tasks Type**: Select **All** tasks, **High Risk tasks** or, for a list of tasks where users have deleted data, select **Delete Tasks**.\n-    - **Search**: Enter criteria to find specific tasks. \n-\n-1. Select **Apply** to display the criteria you've selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-## View the results of your query\n-\n-The **Active Tasks** table displays the results of your query.\n-\n-- **Task Name**: Provides the name of the task.\n-    - To view details about the task, select the down arrow next to the task in the table.\n-\n-        - An icon (![Image of task icon](media/usage-analytics-active-tasks/normal-task.png)) displays to the left of the task name if the task is a **Normal Task** (that is, not risky).\n-        - A highlighted icon (![Image of highlighted task icon](media/usage-analytics-active-tasks/high-risk-deleted-task.png)) displays to the left of the task name if the task involved deleting data — a **High-Delete Task** — or if the task is a **High-Risk Task**.\n-\n-- **Performed on (resources)**: The number of resources on which the task was used.\n-\n-- **Number of Users**: Displays how many users performed tasks. The tasks are organized into the following columns:\n-    - **With Access**: Displays the number of users that have access to the task but haven't accessed it.\n-    - **Accessed**: Displays the number of users that have accessed the task.\n-\n-\n-## Apply filters to your query\n-\n-There are many filter options within the **Active Tasks** screen, including **Authorization System**, **User**, and **Task**.\n-Filters can be applied in one, two, or all three categories depending on the type of information you're looking for.\n-\n-### Apply filters by authorization system type\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-### Apply filters by authorization system\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select accounts from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-### Apply filters by task type\n-\n-You can filter user details by type of user, user role, app, or service used, or by resource.\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Task Type** dropdown, select the type of tasks: **All**, **High Risk Tasks**, or **Delete Tasks**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-## Export the results of your query\n-\n-- To view a report of the results of your query as a comma-separated values (CSV) file, select **Export**, and then select **CSV**.\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- To view active resources, see [View analytic information about active resources](usage-analytics-active-resources.md).\n-- To view the permission usage of access keys for a given user, see [View analytic information about access keys](usage-analytics-access-keys.md)."
  },
  {
    "sha": "1d9656faccbab50366695ce402a6a2a6e60fe04f",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/usage-analytics-groups.md",

    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-groups.md?ref=f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd",
    "patch": "@@ -1,149 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: View analytic information about groups in Permissions Management\n-description: How to view analytic information about groups in Permissions Management.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# View analytic information about groups\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-The **Analytics** dashboard in Permissions Management collects detailed information, analyzes, reports on, and visualizes data about all identity types. System administrators can use the information to make informed decisions about granting permissions and reducing risk on unused permissions for:\n-\n-- **Users**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of various identities.\n-- **Groups**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members.\n-- **Active Resources**: Tracks active resources (used in the last 90 days).\n-- **Active Tasks**: Tracks active tasks (performed in the last 90 days).\n-- **Access Keys**: Tracks the permission usage of access keys for a given user.\n-- **Serverless Functions**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions.\n-\n-This article describes how to view usage analytics about groups.\n-\n-## Create a query to view groups\n-\n-When you select **Groups**, the **Usage Analytics** dashboard provides a high-level overview of groups.\n-\n-1. On the main **Analytics** dashboard, select **Groups** from the  drop-down list at the top of the screen.\n-\n-    The following components make up the **Groups** dashboard:\n-\n-    - **Authorization System Type**: Select the authorization you want to use: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud Platform (GCP).\n-    - **Authorization System**: Select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-    - **Group Type**: Select **All**, **ED** (enterprise directory), or **Local**.\n-    - **Group Activity Status**: Select **All**, **Active**, or **Inactive**.\n-    - **Tasks Type**: Select **All**, **High Risk Tasks**, or **Delete Tasks**\n-    - **Search**: Enter group name to find specific group.\n-1. To display the criteria you've selected, select **Apply**.\n-    - **Reset Filter**: Select to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-## View the results of your query\n-\n-The **Groups** table displays the results of your query:\n-\n-- **Group Name**: Provides the name of the group.\n-    - To view details about the group, select the down arrow.\n-- A **Group Type** icon displays to the left of the group name to describe the type of group (**ED** (enterprise directory) or **Local**).\n-- The **Domain/Account** name.\n-- The **Permission Creep Index (PCI)**: Provides the following information:\n-    - **Index**: A numeric value assigned to the PCI.\n-    - **Since**: How many days the PCI value has been at the displayed level.\n-- **Tasks**: Displays the number of **Granted** and **Executed** tasks.\n-- **Resources**: The number of resources used.\n-- **Users**: The number of users who accessed the group.\n-- Select the ellipses **(...)** and select **Tags** to add a tag.\n-\n-## Add a tag to a group\n-\n-1. Select the ellipses **(...)** and select **Tags**.\n-1. From the **Select a Tag** dropdown, select a tag.\n-1. To create a custom tag select **New Custom Tag**, add a tag name, and then select **Create**.\n-1. In the **Value (Optional)** box, enter a value.\n-1. Select the ellipses **(...)** to select **Advanced Save** options, and then select **Save**.\n-1. To add the tag to the serverless function, select **Add Tag**.\n-\n-## View detailed information about a group\n-\n-1. Select the down arrow to the left of the **Group Name**.\n-\n-    The list of **Tasks** organized by **Unused** and **Used** displays.\n-\n-1. Select the arrow to the left of the group name to view details about the task.\n-1. Select **Information** (**i**) to view when the task was last used.\n-1. From the **Tasks** dropdown, select **All Tasks**, **High Risk Tasks**, and **Delete Tasks**.\n-1. The pane on the right displays a list of **Users**, **Policies** for **AWS** and **Roles** for **GCP or AZURE**, and **Tags**.\n-\n-## Apply filters to your query\n-\n-There are many filter options within the **Groups** screen, including filters by **Authorization System Type**, **Authorization System**, **Group Type**, **Group Activity Status**, and **Tasks Type**.\n-Filters can be applied in one, two, or all three categories depending on the type of information you're looking for.\n-\n-### Apply filters by authorization system type\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-### Apply filters by authorization system\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select accounts from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-### Apply filters by group type\n-\n-You can filter user details by type of user, user role, app, or service used, or by resource.\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Group Type** dropdown, select the type of user: **All**, **ED** (enterprise directory), or **Local**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-### Apply filters by group activity status\n-\n-You can filter user details by type of user, user role, app, or service used, or by resource.\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Group Activity Status** dropdown, select the type of user: **All**, **Active**, or **Inactive**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-### Apply filters by tasks type\n-\n-You can filter user details by type of user, user role, app, or service used, or by resource.\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Tasks Type** dropdown, select the type of user: **All**, **High Risk Tasks**, or **Delete Tasks**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-## Export the results of your query\n-\n-- To view a report of the results of your query as a comma-separated values (CSV) file, select **Export**, and then select **CSV**.\n-- To view a list of members of the groups in your query, select **Export**, and then select  **Memberships**.\n-\n-\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- To view active tasks, see [View analytic information about active tasks](usage-analytics-active-tasks.md).\n-- To view assigned permissions and usage by users, see [View analytic information about users](usage-analytics-users.md).\n-- To view active resources, see [View analytic information about active resources](usage-analytics-active-resources.md)."
  },
  {
    "sha": "c94d92c83987434c7cd38c82db674e4030a4be6a",

    "changes": 46,

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-home.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-home.md?ref=f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd",
    "patch": "@@ -1,46 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: View analytic information with the Analytics dashboard in Permissions Management\n-description: How to use the Analytics dashboard in Permissions Management to view details about users, groups, active resources, active tasks, access keys, and serverless functions.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# View analytic information with the Analytics dashboard\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-This article provides a brief overview of the Analytics dashboard in Permissions Management, and the type of analytic information it provides for Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud Platform (GCP).\n-\n-## Display the Analytics dashboard\n-\n-- From the Permissions Management home page, select the **Analytics** tab.\n-\n-    The **Analytics** dashboard displays detailed information about:\n-\n-    - **Users**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage by users. For more information, see [View analytic information about users](usage-analytics-users.md).\n-\n-    - **Groups**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members.  For more information, see [View analytic information about groups](usage-analytics-groups.md).\n-\n-    - **Active Resources**: Tracks resources that have been used in the last 90 days.  For more information, see [View analytic information about active resources](usage-analytics-active-resources.md).\n-\n-    - **Active Tasks**: Tracks tasks that have been performed in the last 90 days.  For more information, see [View analytic information about active tasks](usage-analytics-active-tasks.md).\n-\n-    - **Access Keys**: Tracks the permission usage of access keys for a given user.  For more information, see [View analytic information about access keys](usage-analytics-access-keys.md).\n-\n-    - **Serverless Functions**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions for AWS only.  For more information, see [View analytic information about serverless functions](usage-analytics-serverless-functions.md).\n-\n-    System administrators can use this information to make decisions about granting permissions and reducing risk on unused permissions.\n-\n-\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- To view assigned permissions and usage by users, see [View analytic information about users](usage-analytics-users.md).\n-- To view assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members, see [View analytic information about groups](usage-analytics-groups.md).\n-- To view active resources, see [View analytic information about active resources](usage-analytics-active-resources.md)."
  },
  {
    "sha": "a7c1a4ad80569048dfd611fb672990228a0d40a9",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/usage-analytics-serverless-functions.md",
    "status": "removed",
    "additions": 0,
    "deletions": 106,
    "changes": 106,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-serverless-functions.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-serverless-functions.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-serverless-functions.md?ref=f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd",
    "patch": "@@ -1,106 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: View analytic information about serverless functions in Permissions Management\n-description: How to view analytic information about serverless functions in Permissions Management.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# View analytic information about serverless functions\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-The **Analytics** dashboard in Permissions Management collects detailed information, analyzes, reports on, and visualizes data about all identity types. System administrators can use the information to make informed decisions about granting permissions and reducing risk on unused permissions for:\n-\n-- **Users**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of various identities.\n-- **Groups**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members.\n-- **Active Resources**: Tracks active resources (used in the last 90 days).\n-- **Active Tasks**: Tracks active tasks (performed in the last 90 days).\n-- **Access Keys**: Tracks the permission usage of access keys for a given user.\n-- **Serverless Functions**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions.\n-\n-This article describes how to view usage analytics about serverless functions.\n-\n-## Create a query to view serverless functions\n-\n-When you select **Serverless Functions**, the **Analytics** dashboard provides a high-level overview of tasks used by various identities.\n-\n-1. On the main **Analytics** dashboard, select **Serverless Functions** from the  dropdown list at the top of the screen.\n-\n-    The following components make up the **Serverless Functions** dashboard:\n-\n-    - **Authorization System Type**: Select the authorization you want to use: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud Platform (GCP).\n-    - **Authorization System**: Select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-    - **Search**: Enter criteria to find specific tasks.\n-1. Select **Apply** to display the criteria you've selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-## View the results of your query\n-\n-The **Serverless Functions** table displays the results of your query.\n-\n-- **Function Name**: Provides the name of the serverless function.\n-    - To view details about a serverless function, select the down arrow to the left of the function name.\n-- A **Function Type** icon displays to the left of the function name to describe the type of serverless function, for example **Lambda function**.\n-- The **Permission Creep Index (PCI)**: Provides the following information:\n-    - **Index**: A numeric value assigned to the PCI.\n-    - **Since**: How many days the PCI value has been at the displayed level.\n-- **Tasks**: Displays the number of **Granted** and **Executed** tasks.\n-- **Resources**: The number of resources used.\n-- **Last Activity On**: The date the function was last accessed.\n-- Select the ellipses **(...)**, and then select **Tags** to add a tag.\n-\n-## Add a tag to a serverless function\n-\n-1. Select the ellipses **(...)** and select **Tags**.\n-1. From the **Select a Tag** dropdown, select a tag.\n-1. To create a custom tag select **New Custom Tag**, add a tag name, and then select **Create**.\n-1. In the **Value (Optional)** box, enter a value.\n-1. Select the ellipses **(...)** to select **Advanced Save** options, and then select **Save**.\n-1. To add the tag to the serverless function, select **Add Tag**.\n-\n-## View detailed information about a serverless function\n-\n-1. Select the down arrow to the left of the function name to display the following:\n-\n-    - A list of **Tasks** organized by **Used** and **Unused**.\n-    - **Versions**, if a version is available.\n-\n-1. Select the arrow to the left of the task name to view details about the task.\n-1. Select **Information** (**i**) to view when the task was last used.\n-1. From the **Tasks** dropdown, select **All Tasks**, **High Risk Tasks**, and **Delete Tasks**.\n-\n-\n-## Apply filters to your query\n-\n-You can filter the **Serverless Functions** results by **Authorization System Type** and **Authorization System**.\n-\n-### Apply filters by authorization system type\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-### Apply filters by authorization system\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select accounts from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- To view active resources, see [View analytic information about active resources](usage-analytics-active-resources.md).\n-- To view the permission usage of access keys for a given user, see [View analytic information about access keys](usage-analytics-access-keys.md)."
  },
  {
    "sha": "87e3939708749108c164101c929573b5f57ca11c",

    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-users.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-users.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-users.md?ref=f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd",
    "patch": "@@ -1,160 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: View analytic information about users in Permissions Management\n-description: How to view analytic information about users in Permissions Management.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# View analytic information about users\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-The **Analytics** dashboard in Permissions Management collects detailed information, analyzes, reports on, and visualizes data about all identity types. System administrators can use the information to make informed decisions about granting permissions and reducing risk on unused permissions for:\n-\n-- **Users**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of various identities.\n-- **Groups**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members.\n-- **Active Resources**: Tracks active resources (used in the last 90 days).\n-- **Active Tasks**: Tracks active tasks (performed in the last 90 days).\n-- **Access Keys**: Tracks the permission usage of access keys for a given user.\n-- **Serverless Functions**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions.\n-\n-This article describes how to view usage analytics about users.\n-\n-## Create a query to view users\n-\n-When you select **Users**, the **Analytics** dashboard provides a high-level overview of tasks used by various identities.\n-\n-1. On the main **Analytics** dashboard, select **Users** from the  drop-down list at the top of the screen.\n-\n-    The following components make up the **Users** dashboard:\n-\n-    - **Authorization System Type**: Select the authorization you want to use: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud Platform (GCP).\n-    - **Authorization System**: Select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders***.\n-    - **Identity Type**: Select **All** identity types, **User**, **Role/App/Service a/c** or **Resource**.\n-    - **Search**: Enter criteria to find specific tasks.\n-1. Select **Apply** to display the criteria you've selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-## View the results of your query\n-\n-The **Identities** table displays the results of your query.\n-\n-- **Name**: Provides the name of the group.\n-    - To view details about the group, select the down arrow.\n-- The **Domain/Account** name.\n-- The **Permission Creep Index (PCI)**: Provides the following information:\n-    - **Index**: A numeric value assigned to the PCI.\n-    - **Since**: How many days the PCI value has been at the displayed level.\n-- **Tasks**: Displays the number of **Granted** and **Executed** tasks.\n-- **Resources**: The number of resources used.\n-- **User Groups**: The number of users who accessed the group.\n-- **Last Activity On**: The date the function was last accessed.\n--  The ellipses **(...)**: Select **Tags** to add a tag.\n-\n-    If you're using AWS, another selection is available from the ellipses menu: **Auto Remediate**. You can use this option to remediate your results automatically.\n-\n-## Add a tag to a user\n-\n-1. Select the ellipses **(...)** and select **Tags**.\n-1. From the **Select a Tag** dropdown, select a tag.\n-1. To create a custom tag select **New Custom Tag**, add a tag name, and then select **Create**.\n-1. In the **Value (Optional)** box, enter a value.\n-1. Select the ellipses **(...)** to select **Advanced Save** options, and then select **Save**.\n-1. To add the tag to the serverless function, select **Add Tag**.\n-\n-## Set the auto-remediate option (AWS only)\n-\n-- Select the ellipses **(...)** and select **Auto Remediate**.\n-\n-    A message displays to confirm that your remediation settings are automatically updated.\n-\n-## Apply filters to your query\n-\n-There are many filter options within the **Users** screen, including filters by **Authorization System**, **Identity Type**, and **Identity State**.\n-Filters can be applied in one, two, or all three categories depending on the type of information you're looking for.\n-\n-### Apply filters by authorization system type\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-### Apply filters by authorization system\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select accounts from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-### Apply filters by identity type\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Identity Type**, select the type of user: **All**, **User**, **Role/App/Service a/c**, or **Resource**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-### Apply filters by identity subtype\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Identity Subtype**, select the type of user: **All**, **ED** (Enterprise Directory), **Local**, or **Cross Account**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-### Apply filters by identity state\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Identity State**, select the type of user: **All**, **Active**, or **Inactive**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-### Apply filters by identity filters\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Identity Type**, select: **Risky** or **Incl. in PCI Calculation Only**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-### Apply filters by task type\n-\n-You can filter user details by type of user, user role, app, or service used, or by resource.\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Task Type**, select the type of user: **All** or **High Risk Tasks**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-## Export the results of your query\n-\n-- To export a report of the results of your query as a comma-separated values (CSV) file, select **Export**, and then select **CSV**.\n-- To export the data in a detailed comma-separated values (CSV) file format, select **Export** and then select **CSV (Detailed)**.\n-- To export a report of user permissions, select **Export** and then select **Permissions**.\n-\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- To view the permission usage of access keys for a given user, see [View analytic information about access keys](usage-analytics-access-keys.md).\n-- To view assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions, see [View analytic information about serverless functions](usage-analytics-serverless-functions.md)."
  },
  {
    "sha": "54300017ffddc49db86eb97cd97c779f49306469",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/whats-new-in-permissions-management.md",
    "status": "removed",
    "additions": 0,
    "deletions": 101,
    "changes": 101,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fwhats-new-in-permissions-management.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fwhats-new-in-permissions-management.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fwhats-new-in-permissions-management.md?ref=f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd",
    "patch": "@@ -1,101 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: What's new in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management\n-description: View the latest public preview and general availability of features in Permissions Management.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: whats-new\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# What's new in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on October 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-This article provides the latest Public Preview and General Availability information of features in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management. \n-\n-## May 2024\n-\n-### General availability - Microsoft Entra Permissions Management integration for Microsoft Defender for Cloud\n-**Type:** Changed feature   \n-**Service category:**                      \n-**Product capability:** Permissions Management  \n-\n-Deploying applications and infrastructure across multiple clouds has become the norm. Ensuring the security of cloud applications and infrastructure requires integrating identity and permission insights into the overall security strategy. This objective is achieved through the integration of Microsoft Entra Permissions Management with Microsoft Defender for Cloud. \n-\n-Permissions Management capabilities are available to integrate into the Defender for Cloud CSPM plan. Adding the capabilities of [Permissions Management to Defender for Cloud](permissions-management-for-defender-for-cloud.md) strengthens the prevention of security breaches that might occur due to excessive permissions or misconfigurations in the cloud environment. By continuously monitoring and managing cloud entitlements, Permissions Management helps to reduce the attack surface, detect potential threats, and maintain compliance with regulatory standards. These added features make Permissions Management an essential tool to integrate into the capabilities of Defender for Cloud for securing cloud-native applications and protecting sensitive data in the cloud. \n-\n-For instructions on how to enable Permissions Management in your Defender for Cloud environment, see [Enable Permissions Management in Microsoft Defender for Cloud](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2252561)\n-\n-\n-### General availability - Support for PIM-enabled Groups \n-**Type:** Changed feature   \n-**Service category:**                      \n-**Product capability:** Permissions Management  \n-\n-Privileged Identity Management (PIM) for Groups in Microsoft Entra ID allows Permissions Management admins to grant users just-in-time membership and ownership of a security group or a Microsoft 365 group. Nested groups are also supported. For example, if a user is an active member of Group A, and Group A is an eligible member of Group B, the user can activate their membership in Group B. PIM provides a powerful mechanism to manage access and enhance security by granting just-in-time access to critical resources. \n-\n-Microsoft Entra Permissions Management adds the support to read the just-in-time membership along with existing support for direct group membership. It also solves the challenge of having visibility into who has access to what resource with eligible and direct role assignments. This feature enables the complete visibility into RBAC permissions assigned to the identities in different ways and the potential impact on Permissions Creep Index (PCI). A complete list of RBAC role assignments is provisioned directly, via the group membership or by an eligible group member, and can be seen per identity under the Analytics tab. \n-\n-## March 2024\n-\n-### Public Preview - Support for PIM-enabled Groups \n-**Type:** Changed feature   \n-**Service category:**                      \n-**Product capability:** Permissions Management  \n-\n-As multiple customers embrace PIM for groups as a popular feature, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management adds the support to read the just-in-time membership impact on the eligible granted Azure RBAC permissions and Permissions Creep Index (PCI). The feature enables the complete visibility into RBAC permissions assigned to the identities in different ways.  \n- \n-In the Permissions Management console, admins can see the membership eligibility status as well as role eligibility status for Groups. For each identity, admins can get the visibility into the membership eligibility status as well as roles eligibility status. \n-\n-\n-## December 2023\n-\n-### General availability - Permissions Analytics Report PDF\n-\n-**Type:** Changed feature   \n-**Service category:**                      \n-**Product capability:** Permissions Management  \n-\n-The [Permissions Analytics Report (PAR)](product-permissions-analytics-reports.md) lists findings relating to permissions risks across identities and resources in Permissions Management. The PAR is an integral part of the risk assessment process where customers discover areas of highest risk in their cloud infrastructure. This report can be directly viewed in the Permissions Management UI, downloaded in Excel (XSLX) format, and exported as a PDF. The report is available for all supported cloud environments: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud Platform (GCP). \n-\n-The PAR PDF is one part of the overall reporting redesign effort led by the engineering team. As part of this feature release, customers can download all reports (system or custom) with no row limitations in CSV and XSLX formats. \n-\n-\n-## October 2023\n-\n-### Public preview - Permissions Analytics Report PDF for multiple authorization systems\n-\n-**Type:** Changed feature   \n-**Service category:**                        \n-**Product capability:** Permissions Management            \n-\n-The Permissions Analytics Report (PAR) lists findings relating to permissions risks across identities and resources in Permissions Management. The PAR is an integral part of the risk assessment process where customers discover areas of highest risk in their cloud infrastructure. This report can be directly viewed in the Permissions Management UI, downloaded in Excel (XSLX) format, and exported as a PDF. The report is available for all supported cloud environments: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud Platform (GCP).  \n-\n-The PAR PDF has a new design to enhance usability, align with the product UX redesign effort, and address various customer feature requests. [You can download the PAR PDF for up to 10 authorization systems](product-permissions-analytics-reports.md).\n-\n-### General availability - ServiceNow app for Permissions Management\n-\n-**Type:** New feature   \n-**Service category:**                        \n-**Product capability:** Permissions Management\n-\n-The ServiceNow Application for Microsoft Entra Permissions Management enables users to request time-bound, on-demand permissions for multicloud environments (Azure, AWS, GCP) through the ServiceNow portal. This integration aids organizations in enhancing their Zero Trust posture by enforcing the principle of least privilege for multicloud permissions. The ServiceNow app streamlines access permission requests within existing approval workflows.  \n-\n-Get the ServiceNow app in the [ServiceNow app store](https://store.servicenow.com/sn_appstore_store.do#!/store/application/24073ae31bfca9100e564082b24bcb56/1.0.1?referer=%2Fstore%2Fsearch%3Flistingtype%3Dallintegrations%25253Bancillary_app%25253Bcertified_apps%25253Bcontent%25253Bindustry_solution%25253Boem%25253Butility%25253Btemplate%25253Bgenerative_ai%25253Bsnow_solution%26q%3Dentra%2520permissions%2520management&sl=sh). \n-\n-### Public preview - Okta and AWS Identity Center identity provider integrations\n-\n-**Type:** New feature   \n-**Service category:**                        \n-**Product capability:** Permissions Management\n-\n-Permissions Management supports third party identity providers (IdP) integration to get more insight of single sign-on data of permissions assigned in cloud environments. With this information, Permissions Management can provide more accurate analytics. By reading role assignments and user data from the IdP side, Permissions Management more effectively calculates permissions granted, and as a result, reads more precise data on permissions creep. \n-\n-For [Okta Identity Provider integration](how-to-configure-okta-as-an-identity-provider.md), an admin needs to configure the API application to give the access to read Okta users, groups, and apps via Okta APIs. Permissions Management reads Okta users, groups, and apps via Okta APIs. \n-\n-For [AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) Identity Center integration](how-to-configure-aws-iam.md), an admin can provide Permissions Management access to read user and role access configuration data from the management account by running the CloudFormation template (CFT) in their AWS environment. After successful configuration, Permissions Management can read the data to calculate the analytics.\n-"
  }
]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response: This commit introduces a comprehensive set of redirection rules for the Microsoft Entra documentation, primarily aimed at consolidating content related to Permissions Management under a new structure. Additionally, it includes minor updates to cross-tenant access settings, Azure Monitor configuration, and Conditional Access documentation, along with the removal of several deprecated Permissions Management articles.

{"content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: [
  {
    "sha": "62d7e737cdd313a56ae9845e9f47e8d613e68401",
    "filename": "docs/fundamentals/whats-new.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 180,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 180,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fwhats-new.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fwhats-new.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fwhats-new.md?ref=f60c40547017684301b31ed4d6a5d3b146b0d3fd",
    "patch": "@@ -22,6 +22,186 @@ This article provides information about the latest releases and change announcem\n \n >Get notified about when to revisit this page for updates by copying and pasting this URL: `https://learn.microsoft.com/api/search/rss?search=%22Release+notes+-+Azure+Active+Directory%22&locale=en-us` into your ![RSS feed reader icon](./media/whats-new/feed-icon-16x16.png) feed reader.\n \n+## September 2025\n+\n+### Public Preview - Use SMS as a verification method in password reset flows in Microsoft Entra External ID \n+\n+**Type:** New feature    \n+**Service category:** B2C - Consumer Identity Management        \n+**Product capability:** B2B/B2C    \n+\n+We’re excited to announce the **public preview of SMS for self-service password reset (SSPR) in Microsoft Entra External ID**. This change is actively rolling out to all tenants in production by end of October. \n+\n+**What’s New**\n+\n+- **SMS Authentication for Password Reset:** End users can now verify their identity via SMS when using the *“forgot password”* or self-service password reset flow. Previously, only email one-time passcodes were supported.\n+\n+- **Enhanced Security:** If users have two or more registered methods for password reset, they'll now be required to verify their identity with at least two methods, adding an extra layer of protection.\n+\n+- **Fraud Protection:** With built-in integration to the Phone Reputation platform, telephony activity is processed in real time to identify risks. Each request is returned with an Allow, Block, or Challenge decision to help protect against telephony fraud.\n+\n+- **Billing:** SMS for password reset is a part of add-on feature with tiered pricing based on location/region. Charges per SMS include the fraud protection services. For more information, see:  [SMS pricing tiers by country/region](../external-id/customers/concept-multifactor-authentication-customers.md#sms-pricing-tiers-by-countryregion).\n+\n+---\n+\n+### Public Preview - Microsoft Security Copilot Access Review Agent in Microsoft Entra\n+\n+**Type:** New feature    \n+**Service category:** Access Reviews        \n+**Product capability:** Identity Governance    \n+\n+Say goodbye to time-consuming research and the uncertainty of rushed decisions. With the public preview of the [Microsoft Security Copilot Access Review Agent in Microsoft Entra](https://aka.ms/ARAgent), we’re bringing the power of AI directly into the heart of access governance.\n+\n+The agent works for your reviewers by automatically gathering insights and generating recommendations to help them make fast, accurate access decisions. Reviewers are guided through a natural, conversational flow right inside Microsoft Teams, so they can make the final call with confidence and clarity.\n+\n+---\n+\n+### General Availability - Cross-tenant synchronization (cross-cloud)\n+\n+**Type:** New feature    \n+**Service category:** Provisioning        \n+**Product capability:** Collaboration    \n+\n+Automate creating, updating, and deleting users across tenants across Microsoft clouds. The following combinations are supported:\n+\n+*   Commercial -> US Gov\n+*   US Gov -> Commercial\n+*   Commercial -> China\n+\n+For more information, see: [Configure cross-tenant synchronization](../identity/multi-tenant-organizations/cross-tenant-synchronization-configure.md)\n+\n+---\n+\n+### General Availability - Dedicated new 1st party resource application to enable AD to Microsoft Entra ID sync using Microsoft Entra Connect Sync or Cloud Sync\n+\n+**Type:** Plan for change    \n+**Service category:** Microsoft Entra Connect    \n+**Product capability:** Microsoft Entra Connect    \n+\n+As part of ongoing security hardening, Microsoft has deployed a dedicated first-party application to enable the synchronization between Active Directory and Microsoft Entra ID. This new application will manifest as a first party service principal called the \"Microsoft Entra AD Synchronization Service\" (Application ID: 6bf85cfa-ac8a-4be5-b5de-425a0d0dc016) and will be visible in the Enterprise Applications experience within the Microsoft Entra admin center. This application is critical for the continued operation of on-premises to Microsoft Entra ID synchronization functionality through Microsoft Entra Connect.\n+\n+Microsoft Entra Connect now uses this first party application to synchronize between Active Directory and Microsoft Entra ID. Customers are required to upgrade to version **2.5.79.0** or later by **September 2026**. \n+\n+We'll auto-upgrade customers where supported. For customers who wish to be auto-upgraded, [ensure that you have auto-upgrade configured](../identity/hybrid/connect/how-to-connect-install-automatic-upgrade.md).  \n+\n+The Microsoft Entra Connect Sync .msi installation file for this change is exclusively available on Microsoft Entra admin center under [Microsoft Entra Connect](https://entra.microsoft.com/#view/Microsoft_AAD_Connect_Provisioning/AADConnectMenuBlade/~/GetStarted).\n+\n+Check our [version history page](../identity/hybrid/connect/reference-connect-version-history.md) for more details on available versions.\n+\n+---\n+\n+### Public Preview - App management policies portal experience\n+\n+**Type:** New feature    \n+**Service category:** Enterprise Apps    \n+**Product capability:** Directory    \n+\n+App management policies allow administrators to improve the security of their organization by setting rules on how applications in their organization can be configured. They can use them to block insecure configurations like password credentials. These policies have been available through the Microsoft Graph API, but can now also be configured using the Microsoft Entra admin center, under the Enterprise applications experience.\n+\n+Learn more about [how to configure app management policies](https://aka.ms/app-mgmt-policy-ux-docs).\n+\n+---\n+\n+### Public Preview - Delegate approvals in My Access\n+\n+**Type:** New feature    \n+**Service category:** Entitlement Management    \n+**Product capability:** Entitlement Management    \n+\n+Users can now delegate their access package approvals in My Access. Approvers can assign another individual to respond to access package approval requests on their behalf. The original approvers can still respond to their approvals during the delegation period.  \n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> This feature currently applies only to access package approvals and will be expanded to support access reviews in November 2025.  \n+  \n+For more information, see: [Delegate approvals in My Access](../id-governance/delegate-approvals-my-access.md).\n+\n+---\n+\n+### Public Preview - Reprocess failed users and workflows in Lifecycle Workflows\n+\n+**Type:** New feature    \n+**Service category:** Lifecycle Workflows    \n+**Product capability:** Identity Governance    \n+\n+Lifecycle Workflows now supports reprocessing of your workflows to help organizations streamline the reprocessing of workflows when errors or failures are discovered. This feature includes the ability to reprocess previous runs of workflows including failed runs or just runs that you might want to process again. Customers can choose from the following options to fit their needs:\n+\n+- Select specific workflow run to be reprocessed\n+- Select which users from the workflow run to be reprocessed. For example either failed users, or all users from the run\n+\n+For more information, see: [Reprocess workflows](../id-governance/reprocess-workflow.md)\n+\n+---\n+\n+### Public Preview - Trigger workflows for inactive employees and guests in Lifecycle Workflows\n+\n+**Type:** New feature    \n+**Service category:** Lifecycle Workflows    \n+**Product capability:** Identity Governance    \n+\n+Lifecycle Workflows now enables customers to configure custom workflows to proactively manage dormant user accounts by automating identity lifecycle actions based on sign-in inactivity. After detecting inactivity, the workflow automatically executes predefined tasks—such as sending inactivity notifications, disabling accounts, or initiating offboarding—for users that exceed the inactivity threshold. Admins can configure the inactivity threshold and scope, ensuring dormant accounts are handled efficiently and consistently - reducing security exposure, reducing license waste, and enforcing governance policies at scale.\n+\n+For more information, see: [Manage inactive users using Lifecycle Workflows (Preview)](../id-governance/lifecycle-workflow-inactive-users.md).\n+\n+---\n+\n+### Retirement - Microsoft Authentication Library to MSAL Recommendations API\n+\n+**Type:** Deprecated    \n+**Service category:** Other    \n+**Product capability:** Developer Experience    \n+\n+We’re retiring the **ADAL to MSAL Recommendations API** on **December 15, 2025**.\n+\n+To continue monitoring authentication library usage, customers can query sign-in logs manually via **Microsoft Graph API**. The relevant data is available in the `authenticationProcessingDetails` field under the key `\"Azure AD App Authentication Library\"`.\n+\n+For guidance, see:\n+\n+*   [Recommendation: Migrate from Microsoft Authentication Library to MSAL](../identity/monitoring-health/recommendation-migrate-from-adal-to-msal.md)\n+*   [Analyze a sign-in with Microsoft Graph API](/azure/azure-monitor/reference/tables/aadnoninteractiveusersigninlogs)\n+\n+No action is required to disable the API.\n+\n+---\n+\n+### Deprecation - Automatically capture sign-in fields for an app in Microsoft Entra admin center. \n+\n+**Type:** Deprecated    \n+**Service category:** My Apps    \n+**Product capability:** Platform    \n+\n+The “*Automatically capture sign-in fields for an app*” option in the Microsoft Entra admin center is retired. Existing apps already configured with this feature continues to work, but it will no longer be available for new configurations. Going forward, admins should use the “*Capture sign-in fields for an app*”. This requires the MyApps Secure Sign-In Extension, available for Microsoft Edge and Chrome. \n+\n+For more information, see: [Capture sign-in fields for an app](../identity/enterprise-apps/troubleshoot-password-based-sso.md#capture-sign-in-fields-for-an-app) \n+\n+To learn about our passwordless strategy, see:[Passwordless is here and at scale](https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/blog/microsoft-entra-blog/passwordless-is-here-and-at-scale/2810639).\n+\n+---\n+\n+### Public Preview - Global Secure Access Internet profile support for iOS client\n+\n+**Type:** New feature    \n+**Service category:** Internet Access    \n+**Product capability:** Network Access    \n+\n+We're excited to announce the Internet Access support with iOS app. This feature protects access to internet and SaaS apps with an identity-based Secure Web Gateway (SWG), blocking threats, unsafe content, and malicious traffic from the iPhones and iPads.\n+\n+Global Secure Access client on mobile platforms requires no new agent installation/deployment for secure access to their resources, and uses existing MDE (Microsoft Defender for Endpoint) to route traffic through Microsoft SSE for both Microsoft 365, internet access and private access.\n+\n+For more information, see: [Global Secure Access client for iOS (Preview)](../global-secure-access/how-to-install-ios-client.md).\n+\n+---\n+\n+### Public Preview - Basic HTML support in Lifecycle Workflow custom email notifications\n+\n+**Type:** New feature    \n+**Service category:** Lifecycle Workflows    \n+**Product capability:** Identity Governance    \n+\n+Now customers can further customize their Lifecycle workflows email notifications to personalize, or emphasize, specific information using basic HTML elements. Email notifications can now be customized to include sending links using HTML hyperlinks and basic text formatting like bold, italics, and underline. For more information, see: [Customize emails sent from workflow tasks](../id-governance/customize-workflow-email.md).\n+\n+---\n+\n+\n ## August 2025\n \n ### General Availability - Microsoft Entra ID Protection: Improved detection quality"
  },

URLs that need to be allowed for PSSO registration flows\n-Please ensure that traffic to the URLs listed [here](./plan-device-deployment.md#network-requirements-for-device-registration-with-microsoft-entra) is allowed by default and explicitly exempted from TLS interception or inspection. This is critical for registration and device auth flows that rely on TLS challenges to complete successfully.\n+Please ensure that traffic to the URLs listed **[here](./plan-device-deployment.md#network-requirements-for-device-registration-with-microsoft-entra)** is allowed by default and explicitly exempted from TLS interception or inspection. This is critical for registration and device auth flows that rely on TLS challenges to complete successfully.\n \n #### 2. URLs that need to be exempted for PSSO token acquisition and token refresh flows\n Please ensure below URLs are exempted from TLS interception/inspection so that Platform SSO token acquisition and refresh can be successfully performed on Platform SSO targeted devices:"

ai_summary.Response: This commit introduces significant updates to the Microsoft Entra documentation, primarily focusing on new features and changes rolled out in September 2025. Key additions include public previews for SMS verification in Microsoft Entra External ID password reset, and the Microsoft Security Copilot Access Review Agent. General availability is announced for cross-tenant synchronization and a new dedicated resource application for AD to Microsoft Entra ID sync. Several deprecations and retirements are also noted, alongside new features for Global Secure Access, Lifecycle Workflows, and My Access, enhancing security and user experience. A minor correction was made to a link in the macOS platform single sign-on extension troubleshooting guide.

Microsoft Entra ID P2 or Microsoft ID Governance for entitlement managed and access reviews |\n+\n ## Protect networks\n \n Protect your network perimeter." }, { "sha": "1296ce5b482f038c7a2254ea8d467fe58eff9930", "filename": "docs/fundamentals/custom-security-attributes-overview.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 0, "changes": 1, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/db355f30fc38b3641f07db65cd091ed9b767b096/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fcustom-security-attributes-overview.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/db355f30fc38b3641f07db65cd091ed9b767b096/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fcustom-security-attributes-overview.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fcustom-security-attributes-overview.md?ref=db355f30fc38b3641f07db65cd091ed9b767b096", "patch": "@@ -37,6 +37,7 @@ Custom security attributes **aren't** supported in the following areas:\n \n - [Microsoft Entra Domain Services](/entra/identity/domain-services/overview)\n - [Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) token claims](~/identity-platform/saml-claims-customization.md)\n+- [JSON Web Token claims](/entra/identity-platform/security-tokens)\n \n ## Features of custom security attributes\n " }, { "sha": "848e3805fc5a79d2f9e67653ab84641e796e1f01", "filename": "docs/global-secure-access/concept-b2b-guest-access.md", "status": "added", "additions": 44, "deletions": 0, "changes": 44, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/db355f30fc38b3641f07db65cd091ed9b767b096/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fconcept-b2b-guest-access.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/db355f30fc38b3641f07db65cd091ed9b767b096/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fconcept-b2b-guest-access.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fconcept-b2b-guest-access.md?ref=db355f30fc38b3641f07db65cd091ed9b767b096", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,44 @@\n+---\n+title: Learn about Global Secure Access B2B Guest Access (Preview)\n+description: Learn how Global Secure Access enables secure B2B guest access for external partners through Windows 365 and Azure Virtual Desktop with enhanced security controls.\n+author: kenwith \n+ms.author: kenwith\n+manager: dougeby\n+ms.topic: concept-article\n+ms.date: 09/30/2025\n+ms.service: global-secure-access\n+ms.reviewer: cagautham\n+ai-usage: ai-assisted\n+---\n+\n+# Overview of B2B guest access in Global Secure Access (preview)\n+Many organizations collaborate with external partners like vendors, contractors, and other businesses. To enable secure collaboration, resource tenants can grant users from other organizations access to their resources. Traditional solutions for external access often lack visibility and granular security controls.\n+\n+Global Secure Access, built into Microsoft Entra, addresses these challenges by leveraging existing B2B guest identities. This integration provides enhanced security features, including full Conditional Access, Continuous Access Evaluation, and cross-tenant trust, helping organizations manage and secure external user access more effectively.\n+\n+## Enable B2B guest access for Azure Virtual Desktop and Windows 365\n+\n+You can enable Global Secure Access on Windows 365 and Azure Virtual Desktop instances that support external identities to provide B2B guest access. With this capability, external users—such as guests, partners, and contractors—from other organizations can securely access resources in your tenant (the resource tenant). As a resource tenant administrator, you can configure Private Access, Internet Access, and Microsoft 365 traffic policies for these third-party users, helping ensure secure and controlled access to your organization's resources.\n+\n+[![Diagram showing an overview of B2B guest access in Global Secure Access.](media/concept-b2b-guest-access/guest-access-overview.png)](media/concept-b2b-guest-access/guest-access-overview.png#lightbox)\n+\n+To enable B2B guest access for Windows 365 or Azure Virtual Desktop (AVD) virtual machines using Global Secure Access, follow these steps:\n+\n+1. Configure your Windows 365 or Azure Virtual Desktop VM instance to use external ID linking. Learn more in [Configure external ID linking](/azure/virtual-desktop/authentication#external-identity).\n+\n+1. Onboard your organization to Global Secure Access. See [onboarding instructions](/entra/global-secure-access/overview-what-is-global-secure-access#licensing-overview).\n+\n+1. Set up one or more Global Secure Access traffic forwarding profiles and assign them to users with external IDs. Learn more in [Configure traffic forwarding profiles](/entra/global-secure-access/quickstart-access-admin-center) and [Assign users to profiles](/entra/external-id/what-is-b2b).\n+\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client on the virtual machines. See [Installation guide for the Global Secure Access client](/entra/global-secure-access/how-to-install-windows-client).\n+\n+Once configured, the Global Secure Access client automatically connects to the tenant associated with the VM instance using the external ID.\n+\n+## Related content\n+\n+- [Global Secure Access client for Windows](how-to-install-windows-client.md)\n+- [Global Secure Access client for Android](how-to-install-android-client.md)\n+- [Global Secure Access client for macOS](how-to-install-macos-client.md)\n+- [Global Secure Access client for iOS](how-to-install-ios-client.md)\n+- [Client for Windows version release notes](reference-windows-client-release-history.md)\n+- [Known At this time, only change requests (CHG) are supported.\n+\n+To use the ServiceNow integration, your organization must have the [ServiceNow plugin](/copilot/security/plugin-servicenow) configured.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization/agent-service-now-integration-setting.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the ServiceNow integration settings.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization/agent-service-now-integration-setting.png\":::\n+\n+When the ServiceNow plugin is turned on in the Conditional Access optimization agent settings, each new suggestion from the agent creates a ServiceNow incident. ai_summary.Response: This commit introduces new documentation for B2B guest access within Global Secure Access, detailing its use with Azure Virtual Desktop and Windows 365, alongside limitations. It also enhances the Conditional Access agent optimization guide with ServiceNow integration details and adds an image related to this feature. Other updates include adding JSON Web Token claims to the unsupported list for custom security attributes and a minor adjustment to the date in the Microsoft Entra ID Protection export data guide. Finally, a minor edit is made to the BIC Cloud Design provisioning tutorial's attribute mapping.

ai_summary.Response: This commit introduces a minor documentation update to clarify that custom security attributes are not supported in JSON Web Token (JWT) claims. Additionally, it refines the attribute mapping table in a tutorial for provisioning BIC Cloud Design users, removing the "roles" attribute as it's no longer marked as required by the application.

ai_summary.Response: This commit introduces new recommendations for protecting tenants and isolating production systems within Microsoft Entra ID. It adds a section detailing various security checks and their minimum required licenses, focusing on restricting guest access, managing external collaboration, and securing app instances. These additions aim to enhance tenant security and isolation.

Under the **Mappings** section, select **Synchronize Microsoft Entra groups to BIC Cloud Design**.\n "
}. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response:
Here's a summary of the changes:

The modification updates the attribute mapping table within the BIC Cloud Design provisioning tutorial documentation. Specifically, the `roles[primary eq "True"].value` attribute has been removed from the list of required attributes for BIC Cloud Design.

    "patch": "@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@ author: omondiatieno\n manager: mwongerapk\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 08/04/2025\n+ms.date: 09/19/2025\n ms.subservice: hybrid-cloud-sync\n ms.author: jomondi\n ms.custom: no-azure-ad-ps-ref, sfi-image-nochange\n@@ -52,6 +52,82 @@ To add synced users, follow these steps:\n 9. It should successfully add the user to the group.\n 10. On the far left, select **All groups**. Repeat this process by using the **Sales** group, and add **Lola Jacobson** to that group.\n \n+## Prepare groups for Group SOA conversion and provisioning\n+\n+You can preserve the original organizational unit (OU) of on-premises groups and provision the groups back to their original Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) after you convert Group SOA to the cloud. Complete the following steps to prepare the groups for provisioning to AD DS with their original OU path.\n+\n+### Change the group scope for the AD DS groups to Universal\n+\n+1. Open Active Directory Administrative Center.\n+1. Right-click a group, click **Properties**.\n+1. In the **Group** section, select **Universal** as the group scope.\n+1. Click **Save**.\n+\n+### Populate a custom attribute in AD DS\n+\n+You can store the OU path in a custom attribute or any other attribute like *info*. For more information about how to sync custom attributes, see [Custom attribute mapping](/entra/identity/hybrid/cloud-sync/tutorial-directory-extension-group-provisioning). In this example, the OU oath is stored in *extensionAttribute13*.\n+\n+Run the following cmdlet to extract the OU from each group's distinguished name (DN) and store it in the *extensionAttribute13* attribute. \n+\n+```powershell\n+Get-ADGroup -Filter * -SearchBase \"DC=contoso,DC=com\" | ForEach-Object { \n+    $ou = ($_.DistinguishedName -split \",\", 2)[1]  # Extract OU path \n+    Set-ADGroup -Identity $_.DistinguishedName -Replace @{extensionAttribute13 = $ou} \n+} \n+```\n+\n+### Enable sync for the custom attribute in the sync client\n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least an [Hybrid Identity Administrator](~/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#hybrid-identity-administrator).\n+1. Browse to **Identity** > **Provisioning** > **Cloud Sync**. \n+1. Select your Cloud Sync configuration. \n+1. Under **Attribute Mapping**, for Group objects: \n+   1. Click **Edit Mapping** \n+   1. Add a new mapping: \n+\n+     | Setting | Value |\n+     |---------|-------|\n+     | Source attribute | extensionAttribute13 |\n+     | Target attribute | onPremisesExtensionAttributes.extensionAttribute13|\n+     | Match objects | Leave unchecked |\n+     | Apply this mapping | Always |\n+\n+### Confirm the custom attribute sync in Microsoft Entra ID\n+\n+   #### [**Microsoft Graph PowerShell**](#tab/PowerShell)\n+\n+   ```powershell\n+   Get-MgGroup -GroupId <groupId> | Select -ExpandProperty OnPremisesExtensionAttributes \n+   ```\n+\n+   #### [**Graph Explorer**](#tab/GE)\n+\n+   ```https\n+   GET https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/groups/{group-id}?$select=onPremisesExtensionAttributes \n+   ```\n+\n+   You should see: \n+\n+   ```https\n+   { \n+     \"onPremisesExtensionAttributes\": { \n+       \"extensionAttribute13\": \"OU=Finance,DC=contoso,DC=com\" \n+     } \n+   } \n+   ```\n+   ---\n+\n+### Provision SOA converted groups with the custom attribute\n+\n+When you configure **Provisioning**, use the synced attribute to control the target OU. \n+ \n+1. In your **Provisioning** configuration, map onPremisesExtensionAttributes.extensionAttribute13 to a custom variable such as *preferredOU*. \n+2. Use an expression like this example to handle fallback. This expression uses the original OU if it's available, or falls back to a default OU that you specify. You can change extensionAttribute13 later to override the value. \n+\n+   ```\n+   IIF(IsNullOrEmpty([extensionAttribute13]), \"OU=<Enter your default OU name>,DC=contoso,DC=com\", [extensionAttribute13]) \n+   ```\n+\n ## Configure provisioning\n \n To configure provisioning, follow these steps:\n@@ -74,7 +150,7 @@ To configure provisioning, follow these steps:\n \n    9. There are two possible approaches to set the OU:\n \n-      - You can preserve the original OU path from on-premises. With this approach, you need to set the attribute mapping based on an extensionAttribute value. For more information, see [Preserve the original OU path](how-to-preserve-original-organizational-unit.md).\n+      - You can preserve the original OU path from on-premises. With this approach, you first need to [Prepare groups for Group SOA conversion and provisioning](#prepare-groups-for-group-soa-conversion-and-provisioning).\n    \n       Or\n "

    "patch": "@@ -139,7 +139,7 @@ Within the same cloud, which clouds can cross-tenant synchronization be used in?\n \n Is [cross-cloud synchronization](cross-tenant-synchronization-configure.md?pivots=cross-cloud-synchronization) supported?\n \n-- Cross-cloud synchronization (such as public cloud to Azure Government) is currently in public preview.\n+- Yes, cross-cloud synchronization (such as public cloud to Azure Government) is supported.\n - For information about the relationship between the Azure Cloud environments and Microsoft 365 (GCC, GCCH), see [Microsoft 365 integration](/azure/security/fundamentals/feature-availability#microsoft-365-integration). \n \n What cloud pairs are supported for cross-cloud synchronization?"

ai_summary.Response:
Here's a summary of the recent changes:

The documentation has been updated to reflect the preview status of web content filtering categories and to clarify the use of Azure Lighthouse for managing external tenant logs. Minor corrections have been made to PowerShell command execution and Log Analytics workspace setup.

Further enhancements include updating the date for enabling source IP restoration and adding a note about necessary Conditional Access policies for non-Microsoft apps. The Android mobile app tutorial has been refined with updated tab names and redirect URI inclusion.

Changes were also made to streamline the documentation for preserving original organisational unit paths during group provisioning in Microsoft Entra Cloud Sync and to update the status of cross-cloud synchronization. Finally, a note regarding the preview status of automatic redemption across different Microsoft cloud environments has been adjusted.

ai_summary.Response:
The commit modifies the documentation for exporting connector logs in Microsoft Entra Global Secure Access.

Key changes include:

*   A minor correction in the PowerShell command for bypassing execution policy, changing `- File` to `-File`.
*   Streamlined the steps for setting up a Log Analytics workspace by removing a redundant instruction to create a Data Collection Endpoint before creating the workspace.
*   Corrected numbering in the "Set up Log Analytics workspace" section, with the creation of a Log Analytics workspace now being step 2, and the creation of a table under the workspace becoming step 3.

ai_summary.Response:
This commit updates the documentation for exporting Global Secure Access connector logs.

Key changes include:

*   **Refined instructions for setting up data collection:** The process for creating a custom log table has been updated to use the "New Custom Log (Direct Ingest)" method, which requires uploading a sample JSON log file.
*   **Clarified Data Collection Rule (DCR) setup:** The steps now guide users to select an existing DCR created during table creation, rather than creating a new one.
*   **Updated verification steps:** The instructions for checking data in Log Analytics have been revised to use Kusto Query Language (KQL) and specify a sample query.
*   **Renamed "Next steps" to "Useful Links":** This change aims to provide a clearer indication of the section's content.

ai_summary.Response:
This commit updates several documentation files related to Microsoft Entra ID. Key changes include:

*   **Error Code Documentation:** The `docs/identity-platform/reference-error-codes.md` file has been updated to correct a link in the AADSTS50124 error description and to add new error codes AADSTS240003 and AADSTS240004.
*   **Server Version Requirements:** Multiple files within the `docs/identity/hybrid/cloud-sync` and `docs/identity/hybrid/connect` directories have been updated to reflect a preference for Windows Server 2022, 2019, or 2016, shifting away from solely referencing Windows Server 2016 as the minimum. This includes updates to prerequisites for Microsoft Entra Connect, cloud sync agents, and provisioning agents.
*   **Date Updates:** Several `ms.date` metadata fields have been advanced to later dates, suggesting ongoing content reviews and updates.

If you already have Microsoft Entra Connect running, ensure that the version is supported.\n \n     >[!NOTE]\n     >Microsoft Entra Connect versions 1.1.557.0, 1.1.558.0, 1.1.561.0, and 1.1.614.0 have a problem related to password hash synchronization. If you *don't* intend to use password hash synchronization in conjunction with Pass-through Authentication, read the [Microsoft Entra Connect release notes](./reference-connect-version-history.md).\n \n-3. Identify one or more additional servers (running Windows Server 2016 or later, with TLS 1.2 enabled) where you can run standalone Authentication Agents. These additional servers are needed to ensure the high availability of requests to sign in. Add the servers to the same Active Directory forest as the users whose passwords you need to validate.\n+3. Identify another server that runs Windows Server 2022, Windows Server 2019, or Windows Server 2016 with TLS 1.2 enabled where you can run standalone Authentication Agents. These additional servers are needed to ensure the high availability of requests to sign in. Add the servers to the same Active Directory forest as the users whose passwords you need to validate.\n \n     >[!IMPORTANT]\n     >In production environments, we recommend that you have a minimum of 3 Authentication Agents running on your tenant. There's a system limit of 40 Authentication Agents per tenant. And as best practice, treat all servers running Authentication Agents as Tier 0 systems (see [reference](/windows-server/identity/securing-privileged-access/securing-privileged-access-reference-material))."

ai_summary.Response: The provided commit history indicates updates across several Microsoft Entra ID documentation pages, primarily concerning hybrid identity solutions. The changes focus on clarifying and standardising the supported Windows Server versions for agent installations and related prerequisites. Specifically, Windows Server 2022, 2019, and 2016 are now consistently listed as the recommended or supported operating systems for various hybrid identity components, including cloud sync agents and Microsoft Entra Connect installations. Additionally, some documentation dates have been updated to reflect the latest publication or review.
